NUISANCE: Anything offensive or obnoxious to the health and welfare of the
inhabitants of the city; or any act or thing repugnant to, or creating a hazard
to, or having a detrimental effect on the property of another person or to the
community.
OCCUPANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who
occupies the whole or any part of such building or land whether alone or with
others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this code or the omission of any
act required by the provisions of this code.
OFFICERS: Whenever reference is made in this code to a city officer by title
only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the city of
Pleasant Grove City".
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: As applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint
owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of a part of
such building or land.
PERSON: Includes the singular and the plural, and also means and includes any
person, firm, corporation, association, partnership or any other form of
association or organization.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Shall include every description of money, goods, chattels,
effects, evidence of rights in action and all written instruments by which any
pecuniary obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged,
transferred, increased, defeated, discharged or diminished and every right or
interest therein.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate
to the sale of services, goods, merchandise, articles or things direct to the
consumer.
RIGHT OF WAY: The privilege of the immediate use of the roadway or other
property.
STATE: The state of Utah.
STREET: Includes alleys, lanes, trails, courts, boulevards, public ways, public
squares, public places and sidewalks.
TENANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies
the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or with others.
WHOLESALER AND WHOLESALE DEALER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall
be understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things
to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WILFULLY: When applied to the intent with which an act is done or omitted,
implies simply a purpose or willingness to commit the act or make the omission
referred to. It does not require any intent to violate law, or to injure
another, or to acquire an advantage.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: May include printing and any other mode of representing
words and letters, but when the written signature of any person is required by
law to any official or public writing or bond, it shall be in the proper
handwriting of such person, or in case such person is unable to write, by such
person's proper mark. (1990 Code § 1.04.030; amd. 2003 Code)
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of the city code are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the content of the section and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such sections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify or
in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any
division or section hereof, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so
deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or
reenacted. (2003 Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: Penalties Designated
1-4-2: License Revocation
1-4-3: Applicability; Continuing Offenses; Multiple Regulations
1-4-4: Liability Of Officers
1-4-1: PENALTIES DESIGNATED:
   A.   Whenever no other penalty is prescribed, any violation of any provision
of any ordinance or provision of this code now or hereafter enacted shall be
punished as a class B misdemeanor. Such punishment may include a fine not to
exceed the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or imprisonment for a
period not longer than six (6) months, or both such fine and imprisonment.
   B.   All offenses designated as class B misdemeanors shall be punishable by
a fine not to exceed the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or by
imprisonment for a period not longer than six (6) months, or by both such fine
and imprisonment.
   C.   All offenses designated as class C misdemeanors shall be punishable by
a fine in a sum not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), or by
imprisonment for a period not longer than ninety (90) days, or by both such
fine and imprisonment.
   D.   All offenses designated as infractions shall be punishable by a fine
not to exceed the sum of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (Ord. 97-6, 2-
18-1997; amd. 2003 Code)
1-4-2: LICENSE REVOCATION:
When a person is convicted of a violation of any section of this code, any
license previously issued to him by the city may be revoked by the court or by
the governing body. (1990 Code § 1.12.020)
1-4-3: APPLICABILITY; CONTINUING OFFENSES; MULTIPLE REGULATIONS:
   A.   The penalty provided in this chapter shall be applicable to every
section of this code, the same as though it were a part of each and every
separate section. (1990 Code § 1.12.030)
   B.   Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this code where
any duty is prescribed or obligation imposed, or where any act which is of a
continuing nature or declared to be unlawful, shall be deemed guilty of a class
B misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day such
duty or obligation remains unperformed or such act continues, unless otherwise
specifically provided in this code. (1990 Code § 1.12.030; amd. 2003 Code)
   C.   In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by
different clauses or sections of this code, the prosecuting officer may elect
under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the
same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or
permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other
penalty being enforced.
   D.   Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to do any act constitutes
a breach of any section or provision of this code and there is no fine
specifically declared for such breach, the provisions of this chapter shall
apply; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during or
on which a breach or violation occurs or continues. (1990 Code § 1.12.030)
1-4-4: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of
the governing body to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or employee
is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the duty. (1990
Code § 1.12.040)
CHAPTER 5
OFFICIAL AND CORPORATE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
1-5-1: Corporate Seal
1-5-2: Fiscal Year
1-5-1: CORPORATE SEAL:
   A.   Description: The seal heretofore provided and used by and for the city,
circular in form, one and eleven-sixteenths inches (111/16") in diameter, the
impression on which represents three (3) trees with the words "Pleasant Grove
City, Utah, Corporate Seal" in the outer circle thereof, near the margin, is
declared to have been, now is, and hereafter shall be the corporate seal of the
city.
   B.   Facsimile: The corporate seal of the city is illustrated below:
   (Ord. 2011-13, 6-21-2011)
1-5-2: FISCAL YEAR:
The fiscal year of the city shall begin July 1 of each year and shall end June
30 of the following year. For convenience in referring to a specific fiscal
year, the fiscal year shall be named fiscal year (the year that the fiscal year
began). For example, the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1999 and ending June 30,
2000, shall be termed "fiscal year 1999", or simply "FY 99". (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-
2002)
CHAPTER 6
FORM OF GOVERNMENT
SECTION:
1-6-1: Municipal Government
1-6-2: Mayor
1-6-3: Administrative Officer
1-6-4: City Council
1-6-1: MUNICIPAL GOVERNMENT:
The municipal government of the city is vested in a governing body which
exercises both legislative and executive powers. The governing body consists of
a council of six (6) members, one of whom is the mayor; the remaining five (5)
are council members. The administrative powers, authority and duties are vested
in the mayor. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
1-6-2: MAYOR:
The mayor shall be a resident of the city and shall be elected at large for a
term of four (4) years, with the term commencing at twelve o'clock (12:00) noon
on the first Monday of January following the municipal election. The mayor
elect shall take the oath of office at said date and time or as soon thereafter
as is practical. The mayor shall hold office for the term for which elected,
unless sooner removed as provided by law, and until a successor is elected and
has qualified. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
1-6-3: ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER:
The mayor may, with the advice and consent of the city council, appoint an
administrative officer to exercise such powers of administration and perform
such duties as outlined in section
1-11-1 of this title. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
1-6-4: CITY COUNCIL:
Each member of the city council shall be a resident of the city and shall be
elected for a term of four (4) years, with the term commencing at twelve
o'clock (12:00) noon on the first Monday of January following the municipal
election. Council members elect shall take the oath of office at said date and
time or as soon thereafter as is practical. Council members shall hold office
for the term for which elected, unless sooner removed as provided by law, and
until a successor is elected and has qualified. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
CHAPTER 7
ELECTIONS
SECTION:
1-7-1: Conduct Of Municipal Elections
1-7-2: Qualifications, Time Of Filing For Elective Office And Filing Fees
1-7-1: CONDUCT OF MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS:
   A.   Nonpartisan Primary System For Municipal Elections Adopted: The
nonpartisan primary system for municipal elections in the city is hereby
adopted as authorized by Utah Code Annotated section 20A-9-404, whereby
candidates for municipal office shall be nominated at a nonpartisan primary
election to be held on the Tuesday following the first Monday in the October
before the regular municipal election.
   B.   Applicable Provisions Of Utah Municipal Election Code Adopted: All
provisions set forth in the Utah municipal election code, Utah Code Annotated
section 20A-9-201 et seq., and all sections pertaining and applicable to the
nonpartisan primary system for municipal elections, are hereby adopted by
reference. (Ord. 2015-19, 5-26-2015)
1-7-2: QUALIFICATIONS, TIME OF FILING FOR ELECTIVE OFFICE AND FILING FEES:
   A.   Qualifications: Candidates for any municipal office shall meet the
following qualifications:
      1.   Candidates shall be registered voters in the municipality.
      2.   Candidates shall be U.S. citizens at the time of filing.
      3.   Candidates shall be residents of Pleasant Grove City. Residency can
be established by:
         a.   Residing in Pleasant Grove City for the twelve (12) consecutive
months immediately before the date of the municipal general election; or
         b.   If the candidate resides in an area recently annexed into the
city, the candidate must have resided in the annexed area of the city for
twelve (12) months.
      4.   Pursuant to Utah constitution, article IV, section 6, any mentally
incompetent person, any person convicted of a felony or any person convicted of
treason or a crime against the elective franchise may not hold office in this
state until the right to vote or hold elective office is restored as provided
by statute.
   B.   Filing For Elective Office And Filing Fees:
      1.   Declaration Of Candidacy: Each person seeking to become a candidate
for a municipal office shall file a declaration of candidacy in person with the
city recorder and pay a thirty five dollar ($35.00) filing fee during office
hours, and not later than five o'clock (5:00) P.M., between June 1 and June 7
of any municipal election year.
      2.   Nominating Petition: Any resident of the city may nominate a
candidate for a municipal office by filing a nomination petition with the city
recorder and paying a thirty five dollar ($35.00) filing fee during office
hours, but not later than five o'clock (5:00) P.M., between June 1 and June 7
of any municipal election year.
      3.   Exception For Deadline: When June 7 is a Saturday or Sunday, the
filing period shall be extended until five o'clock (5:00) P.M. on the following
Monday.
      4.   Write In Candidate: Any person wishing to become a valid write in
candidate shall file a declaration of candidacy with the city recorder and by
paying a thirty five dollar ($35.00) filing fee not later than sixty (60) days
before the municipal general election. (Ord. 2015-19, 5-26-2015)
ARTICLE A.  CAMPAIGN FINANCE DISCLOSURE
SECTION:
1-7A-1: Definitions
1-7A-2: Filing Of Campaign Finance Disclosure Statements
1-7A-3: Contents Of Campaign Finance Statement
1-7A-4: Public Information
1-7A-5: Penalty
1-7A-1: DEFINITIONS:
AGENT OF A CANDIDATE: A. A person acting on behalf of a candidate at the
direction of the reporting entity;
   B.   A person employed by a candidate in the candidate's capacity as a
candidate;
   C.   The personal campaign committee of a candidate;
   D.   A member of the personal campaign committee of a candidate in the
member's capacity as a member of the personal campaign committee of the
candidate; or
   E.   A political consultant of a candidate.
ANONYMOUS CONTRIBUTION LIMIT: Means for each calendar year:
   A.   Fifty dollars ($50.00); or
   B.   An amount less than fifty dollars ($50.00) that is specified in an
ordinance of the Municipality; and
   C.   Is from a donor whose name is unknown.
CANDIDATE: A. A person who:
      1.   Files a declaration of candidacy for Municipal office; or
      2.   Receives contributions, makes expenditures, or gives consent for any
other person to receive contributions or make expenditures to bring about the
person's nomination or election to a Municipal office.
   B.   "Candidate" does not mean a person who files for the Office of Judge.
CONTRIBUTION: A. Any of the following when done for political purposes:
      1.   A gift, subscription, donation, loan, advance, or deposit of money
or anything of value given to a candidate;
      2.   An express, legally enforceable contract, promise, or agreement to
make a gift, subscription, donation, unpaid or partially unpaid loan, advance,
or deposit of money or anything of value to the candidate;
      3.   Any transfer of funds from another reporting entity to the
candidate;
      4.   Compensation paid by any person or reporting entity other than the
candidate for personal services provided without charge to the candidate;
      5.   A loan made by a candidate deposited to the candidate's own
campaign; and
      6.   An in-kind contribution.
   B.   "Contribution" does not include:
      1.   Services provided by an individual volunteering a portion or all of
the individual's time on behalf of the candidate if the services are provided
without compensation by the candidate or any other person;
      2.   Money lent to the candidate by a financial institution in the
ordinary course of business; or
      3.   Goods or services provided for the benefit of a candidate at less
than fair market value that are not authorized by or coordinated with the
candidate.
COORDINATED WITH: Means that goods or services provided for the benefit of a
candidate are provided:
   A.   With the candidate's prior knowledge, if the candidate does not object;
   B.   By agreement with the candidate;
   C.   In coordination with the candidate; or
   D.   Using official logos, slogans, and similar elements belonging to a
candidate.
EXPENDITURE: A. Any of the following made by a candidate or an agent of the
candidate on behalf of the candidate:
      1.   Any disbursement from contributions, receipts, or from a separate
campaign account in a financial institution;
      2.   A purchase, payment, donation, distribution, loan, advance, deposit,
gift of money, or anything of value made for political purposes;
      3.   An express, legally enforceable contract, promise, or agreement to
make any purchase, payment, donation, distribution, loan, advance, deposit,
gift of money, or anything of value for a political purpose;
      4.   Compensation paid by a candidate for personal services rendered by a
person without charge to a reporting entity;
      5.   A transfer of funds between the candidate and a candidate's personal
campaign committee as defined in Utah Code Annotated section 20A-11-101; or
      6.   Goods or services provided by a reporting entity to or for the
benefit of the candidate for political purposes at less than fair market value.
   B.   "Expenditure" does not include:
      1.   Services provided without compensation by an individual volunteering
a portion or all of the individual's time on behalf of a candidate; or
      2.   Money lent to a candidate by a financial institution in the ordinary
course of business.
IN-KIND CONTRIBUTION: Anything of value other than money, that is accepted by
or coordinated with a candidate.
POLITICAL CONSULTANT: A. A person who is paid by a candidate, or paid by
another person on behalf of and with the knowledge of the candidate, to provide
political advice to the candidate.
   B.   "Political consultant" includes a circumstance described in subsection
A of this definition, where the person:
      1.   Has already been paid, with money or other consideration;
      2.   Expects to be paid in the future, with money or other consideration;
or
      3.   Understands that the person may, in the discretion of the candidate
or another person on behalf of and with the knowledge of the candidate, be paid
in the future, with money or other consideration.
POLITICAL PURPOSES: An act done with the intent or in a way to influence or
tend to influence, directly or indirectly, any person to refrain from voting or
to vote for or against any candidate or a person seeking a Municipal office at
any caucus, political convention, or election.
REPORTING ENTITY: A. A candidate;
   B.   A committee appointed by a candidate to act for the candidate;
   C.   A person who holds an elected Municipal office;
   D.   A party committee as defined in Utah Code Annotated section 20A-11-101;
   E.   A political action committee as defined in Utah Code Annotated section
20A-11-101;
   F.   A political issues committee as defined in Utah Code Annotated section
20A-11-101;
   G.   A corporation as defined in Utah Code Annotated section 20A-11-101; or
   H.   A labor organization as defined in Utah Code Annotated section 20A-11-
1501.
REPORTING LIMIT: For each calendar year:
   A.   Fifty dollars ($50.00); or
   B.   An amount lower than fifty dollars ($50.00) that is specified in an
ordinance of the Municipality. (Ord. 2017-32, 5-16-2017)
1-7A-2: FILING OF CAMPAIGN FINANCE DISCLOSURE STATEMENTS:
   A.   Disclosure Requirements:
      1.   Each candidate:
         a.   Shall deposit a contribution in a separate campaign account in a
financial institution; and
         b.   May not deposit or mingle any campaign contributions received
into a personal or business account.
      2.   In a year in which a Municipal primary is held, each candidate who
will participate in the Municipal primary shall file a campaign finance
statement with the Municipal Clerk or Recorder no later than seven (7) days
before the primary election.
      3.   All candidates who are eliminated at a Municipal primary election
shall file with the Recorder a campaign financial statement no later than
thirty (30) days after the Municipal primary election.
      4.   All candidates who are not eliminated at a Municipal primary
election shall file a campaign financial report with the City Recorder no later
than seven (7) days before the Municipal general election, and no later than
thirty (30) days after the Municipal general election.
      5.   A campaign finance statement required under this section is
considered filed if it is received in the Municipal Clerk or Recorder's Office
by five o'clock (5:00) P.M. on the date that it is due.
   B.   Failure To Report By Deadline:
      1.   If a candidate fails to file a campaign finance statement before the
Municipal general election by the deadline as specified in this article, the
City Recorder shall:
         a.   If practicable, remove the candidate's name from the ballot by
blacking out the candidate's name before the ballots are delivered to voters;
or
         b.   If removing the candidate's name from the ballot is not
practicable, inform the voters by any practicable method that the candidate has
been disqualified and that votes cast for the candidate will not be counted;
and
         c.   May not count any votes for that candidate. (Ord. 2017-32, 5-16-
2017)
1-7A-3: CONTENTS OF CAMPAIGN FINANCE STATEMENT:
   A.   Seven Days Before Election (For Candidates Who Run In The Primary And
General Election): The campaign finance statement filed no later than seven (7)
days before the Municipal primary and general election shall include:
      1.   Report all of the candidate's itemized and total:
         a.   Contributions, including in-kind and other nonmonetary
contributions, received up to and including five (5) days before the campaign
finance statement is due, excluding a contribution previously reported; and
         b.   Expenditures made up to and including five (5) days before the
campaign finance statement is due, excluding an expenditure previously
reported; and
      2.   Identify:
         a.   For each contribution, the amount of the contribution and the
name of the donor, if known; and
         b.   For each expenditure, the amount of the expenditure and the name
of the recipient of the expenditure; or
         c.   Report the total amount of all contributions and expenditures if
the candidate receives five hundred dollars ($500.00) or less in contributions
and spends five hundred dollars ($500.00) or less on the candidate's campaign.
      3.   A list of each contribution of more than fifty dollars ($50.00)
received by the candidate, and the name of the donor of the contribution and
the amount of the contribution;
      4.   An aggregate total of all contributions of fifty dollars ($50.00) or
less received by the candidate, even if no contributions are received; and
      5.   A list of each expenditure made for political purposes during the
campaign period, and the name of the recipient and the amount of the
expenditure.
   B.   Thirty Days After General Election (For Candidates Who Run In The
General Election): The campaign finance statement filed no later than thirty
(30) days after the Municipal general election shall include:
      1.   A list of each contribution of more than fifty dollars ($50.00)
received by the candidate and the name of the donor of the contribution and the
amount of the contribution after the cutoff date for the statement filed seven
(7) days before the election; and
      2.   Within thirty (30) days after receiving a contribution that is cash
or a negotiable instrument, exceeds the anonymous contribution limit, a
candidate shall disburse the amount of the contribution to:
         a.   The Treasurer of the State or a political subdivision for deposit
into the State's or political subdivision's General Fund; or
         b.   An organization that is exempt from Federal income taxation under
section 501(c)(3), Internal Revenue Code. (Ord. 2017-32, 5-16-2017)
1-7A-4: PUBLIC INFORMATION:
The campaign finance statements required by this article shall be public
document records and shall be available for public inspection and copying
during all regular City business hours, as required in title 63G, chapter 2, by
the Utah Government Records Access and Management Act (GRAMA). (Ord. 2017-32,
5-16-2017)
1-7A-5: PENALTY:
Any candidate who fails to comply with this article is guilty of an infraction
and shall pay a fine of ten dollars ($10.00) per day for every day they are
late up to a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each and
every failure to file the required campaign financial statement shall
constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2017-32, 5-16-2017)
CHAPTER 8
MAYOR
SECTION:
1-8-1: Duties And Powers Of Mayor
1-8-2: Vacancy
1-8-3: Mayor Pro Tempore
1-8-1: DUTIES AND POWERS OF MAYOR:
   A.   The duly elected mayor shall be the chief executive officer to whom all
employees of the municipality shall report.
   B.   The mayor shall keep the peace and enforce the laws of the city, and
shall ensure that all the laws, ordinances and resolutions are faithfully
executed and observed.
   C.   The mayor shall appoint, with the advice and consent of the city
council, persons to fill municipal offices required by state law and municipal
ordinance, and fill vacancies on committees, commissions and boards of the
municipality as prescribed by ordinance or law. This subsection shall not apply
to managers appointed under Utah Code Annotated section 10-3-830.
   D.   The mayor shall, with the advice and consent of the city council, hire
and make all appointments of department directors as named in section
1-11-4 of this title and department officers and agents, and disciplining or
terminating the same, subject to the advice and consent of the city council.
   E.   The mayor may remit fines and forfeitures and may release any person
imprisoned for violation of any municipal ordinance.
   F.   The mayor shall report such remittance or release to the city council
at its next regular session.
   G.   The mayor shall perform all duties prescribed by law, resolution or
ordinance.
   H.   The mayor shall issue proclamations with the approving vote of the city
council.
   I.   The mayor shall perform additional duties that would include:
      1.   Chairperson of redevelopment agency board 1 ;
      2.   Member of the economic development committee;
      3.   Member of the Utah County council of governments;
      4.   Member of the mountainland association of governments;
      5.   Chairperson of the municipal building authority board.
   J.   The mayor may assign, with the advice and consent of the city council,
members of the council to a broad oversight role with each of the municipal
divisions and the boards, commissions and committees listed below. Voting
rights will be part of the assignment as listed below: (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
      1.   Reserved. (Ord. 2016-21, 9-13-2016)
      2.   Neighborhood advisory board, one, without vote;
      3.   Economic development committee, one, without vote; (Ord. 2002-5, 2-
5-2002)
      4.   Pleasant Grove arts commission, one, without vote; (Ord. 2002-5, 2-
5-2002; amd. Ord. 2003-11, 8-19-2003)
      5.   Historic preservation commission, one, without vote;
      6.   Quality of life commission, one, without vote; (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-
2002)
      7.   Beautification and shade tree commission, one, without vote; (Ord.
2002-5, 2-5-2002; amd. 2003 Code)
      8.   Library board, one, without vote;
      9.   Golf course committee, one, without vote;
      10.   North Pointe solid waste special service district, one, with vote;
      11.   Utah County housing consortium, one, with vote;
      12.   Metropolitan water district board, one, without vote;
   K.   The mayor may at any reasonable time examine and inspect the books,
papers, records or documents of the city or of any officer, employee or agent
of the city.
   L.   The mayor shall report to the city council the condition of the city
and recommend for council consideration any measures the mayor deems to be in
the best interests of the city.
   M.   The mayor shall, when necessary, call on the residents of the city over
the age of twenty one (21) years to assist in enforcing the laws of the state
and ordinances of the municipality.
   N.   The mayor shall execute the policies adopted by the city council as
reflected by council resolutions or by city ordinances which are consistent
with state law. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
   O.   The mayor shall, unless excused, attend all meetings of the city
council, in the capacity of chairperson of the council, with the right to take
part in all discussions and the responsibility to inform the council of the
condition and needs of the municipality and make recommendations and freely
give advice to the council, except that the mayor shall not have the right to
vote in council meetings unless in the case of a tie, when the mayor shall give
the determining vote. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002; amd. 2003 Code)
   P.   With the assistance of the budget and finance officer, the mayor shall
furnish the city council with a written and oral report, at six (6) month
intervals, setting forth the amounts of all budget appropriations, the total
disbursements to date from those appropriations, and the amount of indebtedness
incurred or contracted against each appropriation (including disbursements and
indebtedness incurred and not paid) and the percentage of the appropriations
encumbered to date, which reports shall be made available for public
inspection.
   Q.   The mayor shall authorize the issuance of such rules and regulations
for the general operation of the city which are not in conflict with the laws
of the state or city ordinances.
   R.   The mayor shall prepare and submit to the city council:
      1.   A state of the city report to coincide with submission of the annual
budget; and
      2.   An annual report of the city's financial affairs, within one hundred
eighty (180) days following the close of the city's fiscal year (as established
by state law).
   S.   The mayor may appoint a qualified budget/finance officer to serve in
place of the mayor for the purpose of conforming to the requirements of the
uniform municipal fiscal procedures act and fulfilling the requirements of the
act in all other respects.
   T.   The mayor may create any other offices as may be deemed necessary for
the good government of the city and make appointments to them; regulate and
prescribe the powers and duties of said office, within the general provisions
of the law and ordinances; and establish job descriptions, job functions, job
classifications or reclassifications and compensation therefor, within the
parameters of the pay scale and classification schedules as adopted by city
ordinance and the budget appropriations which are consistent with state law,
and with the advice and consent of the city council. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
 
Notes
1 1. See also title 2, chapter 2, article G of this code.
1-8-2: VACANCY:
If a vacancy should occur in the office of the mayor, the procedures for
midterm vacancies in municipal offices set forth in Utah Code Annotated section
20A-1-510 will be followed. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
1-8-3: MAYOR PRO TEMPORE:
The city council shall annually elect one of its members to act as mayor pro
tempore during the temporary absence or disability of the mayor, who during
such absence or disability shall possess the powers of the mayor. (Ord. 2002-5,
2-5-2002)
CHAPTER 9
CITY COUNCIL
SECTION:
1-9-1: Authority
1-9-2: Meetings
1-9-3: Voting
1-9-4: Emergency Meetings; Notice
1-9-5: Quorum
1-9-6: Rules; Expulsion
1-9-7: Duties
1-9-8: Regulations Prescribed
1-9-9: Vacancies
1-9-1: AUTHORITY:
The mayor and city council are and shall be the legislative and governing body
of the city and as such shall have, exercise and discharge all of the rights,
powers, privileges and authority conferred by law upon the city and shall
perform all duties required of them by law, and shall perform such other acts
and take such other measures, not inconsistent with law, as may be necessary
for the efficient government of the city. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
1-9-2: MEETINGS:
The city council shall hold regular meetings, insofar as practicable, on the
first and third Tuesdays of each month. The regular hour of the meeting shall
be set by resolution. All meetings of the city council shall be held in
compliance with the provisions of Utah Code Annotated title 52, chapter 4, as
amended, relating to open and public meetings. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
1-9-3: VOTING:
   A.   The minimum number of "yes" votes required to pass any ordinance or
resolution, or to take any action by the city council, unless otherwise
prescribed by law, shall be a majority of the members of the quorum, but shall
never be less than three (3).
   B.   Any ordinance, resolution or motion of the city council having fewer
favorable votes than required in this chapter shall be deemed defeated and
invalid; however, a meeting may be adjourned to a specific time by a majority
vote of the city council even though such majority vote is less than that
required in this chapter.
   C.   A majority of the members of the city council, regardless of number,
may fill any vacancy in the city council.
   D.   A roll call vote shall be taken and recorded for all ordinances and
resolutions, and for any action which would create a liability against the
municipality, and in any other case at the request of any member of the
governing body, by a "yes" or a "no" vote, and such roll call vote shall be
recorded.
   E.   Every ordinance or resolution shall be in writing before the vote is
taken.
   F.   Any action taken by the city council in a regular meeting shall not be
reconsidered or rescinded at any special or emergency meeting unless the number
of members of the city council present at the special meeting is equal to or
greater than the number of city council members present at the meeting when the
action was approved. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
1-9-4: EMERGENCY MEETINGS; NOTICE:
If at any time the business of the city requires an emergency or special
meeting of the city council, such meeting may be ordered by the mayor,
administrative officer, or any two (2) members of the city council. The order
shall be entered in the minutes of the next regular city council meeting. The
order shall provide at least three (3) hours' notice of the special meeting,
and notice thereof shall be served by the city recorder or city clerk on each
member who did not sign the order calling the special meeting by delivering the
notice personally or by leaving it at the city council member's usual place of
abode. The personal appearance by a member of any specially called meeting
constitutes a waiver of the notice required by this section. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-
2002)
1-9-5: QUORUM:
   A.   Number Specified: The number of members of the city council necessary
to constitute a quorum is three (3) or more; but a smaller number may adjourn.
   B.   Compelling Attendance: A quorum of the governing body is empowered to
compel the attendance of an absent member and may, when necessary, direct the
police chief to bring in such member under arrest. Should any member of the
council not attend when notified by the proper authority that his or her
presence is necessary to form a quorum, or should any member leave the council
when in session without the consent of the council when such leaving would
break the quorum, that council member shall present an excuse satisfactory to
the council at its next regular meeting, or the city council may fine that
council member in any sum not exceeding fifty dollars ($50.00). (Ord. 2002-5,
2-5-2002)
1-9-6: RULES; EXPULSION:
The city council shall determine its own rules of procedure and may punish its
members for disorderly conduct and, with the concurrence of two-thirds (2/3) of
the members, may expel a member from a meeting for cause. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-
2002)
1-9-7: DUTIES:
The city council is the legislative body of the city and shall act in that
capacity. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
1-9-8: REGULATIONS PRESCRIBED:
The city council shall have the power to prescribe rules and regulations which
are not inconsistent with the laws of the state, as it deems best for the
efficient administration, organization, operation, conduct and business of the
municipality. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
1-9-9: VACANCIES:
   A.   Appointment Of Registered Voter: If any vacancy occurs in the office of
a council member, the city council shall appoint a registered voter in the city
to fill the unexpired term of the office vacated until the January following
the next municipal election, except as otherwise provided in subsection F of
this section.
   B.   Notice Requirements: Before acting to fill the vacancy, the city
council shall:
      1.   Give public notice of the vacancy at least two (2) weeks before the
city council meets to fill the vacancy; and
      2.   Identify, in the notice:
         a.   The date, time and place of the meeting where the vacancy will be
filled; and
         b.   The person to whom a person interested in being appointed to fill
the vacancy may submit his or her name for consideration and any deadline for
submitting it.
   C.   Time Limit; Action Required: If, for any reason, the city council does
not fill the vacancy within thirty (30) days after the vacancy occurs, the city
council shall vote upon the names that have been submitted.
   D.   Appearance; Interviews: The two (2) persons having the highest number
of votes of the city council shall appear before the city council, which may at
its discretion interview these two (2) persons, and the city council shall vote
upon those names.
   E.   Majority Vote Not Received; Fill By Lot: If neither candidate receives
a majority vote of the city council at that time, the vacancy shall be filled
by lot in the presence of the city council.
   F.   Interim Appointment:
      1.   A vacancy in the office of a council member shall be filled by an
interim appointment, followed by an election to fill a two (2) year term, if:
         a.   The vacancy occurs, or a letter of resignation is received by the
municipal executive, at least fourteen (14) days before the deadline for filing
for election in an odd numbered year; and
         b.   Two (2) years of the vacated term will remain after the first
Monday of January following the next municipal election.
      2.   In appointing an interim replacement, the city council shall comply
with the notice requirements of this section.
   G.   Council Member Considered For Appointment: A member of the city council
may not participate in any part of the process established in this section to
fill a vacancy if that member is being considered for appointment to fill the
vacancy. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
CHAPTER 10
OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
SECTION:
1-10-1: Elective Officers
1-10-2: Appointive Officers; Appointment
1-10-3: Term Of Office Of Appointive Officers
1-10-4: Oaths And Bonds
1-10-5: Salaries; Generally
1-10-6: Review Of Salaries; Public Hearing
1-10-7: Salaries Of Elective Officers
1-10-8: Powers And Duties
1-10-9: Delivery Of Property To Successor
1-10-1: ELECTIVE OFFICERS:
   A.   The Municipal government of the City is vested in a Mayor and City
Council, to be composed of a Mayor and five (5) Council members to be elected
at large (see chapters 6 and 7 of this title).
   B.   All elective officers shall be chosen by qualified voters of the City.
No person shall be eligible for any elective office who is not a qualified
elector of the City, nor shall any person who is a defaulter to the corporation
be eligible for any elective office. (Ord. 2017-47, 11-14-2017)
1-10-2: APPOINTIVE OFFICERS; APPOINTMENT:
   A.   Appointments: The Mayor, with the advice and consent of the City
Council, may appoint and fill vacancies in all appointed offices pursuant to
Utah Code Annotated 10-3-916. Appointed offices within the City of Pleasant
Grove are:
City Administrator 1
City Recorder 2
Deputy City Recorder
City Treasurer
Department directors
City Attorney
Justice of the Peace
Fire Chief
Police Chief
Budget/Finance Officer
City Engineer
Building official
   B.   Continue In Office: All appointed officers shall continue in office
until their successors are appointed and qualified.
   C.   Temporary Appointments: Any person filling one of these offices on a
temporary basis shall also be approved with the advice and consent of the City
Council. (Ord. 2017-47, 11-14-2017)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  1-11-1 of this title.
2 2. See also subsection 1-11-5-1A of this title.
1-10-3: TERM OF OFFICE OF APPOINTIVE OFFICERS:
All appointive officers and employees of municipalities, other than members of
the Police Department, Fire Department, heads of departments, and
Superintendents, shall hold their employment without limitation of time, being
subject to discharge or dismissal only as hereinafter provided. (Ord. 2017-47,
11-14-2017)
1-10-4: OATHS AND BONDS:
All officers, whether elected or appointed, shall take, subscribe and file the
constitutional oath of office before they enter upon the duties of their
respective office, and every such officer shall, before entering upon the
duties of his office, execute a personal bond with good and sufficient sureties
or shall be covered by a policy of crime or theft insurance payable to the City
in such penal sum as may by resolution or ordinance be directed and conditioned
for the faithful performance of the duties of the office and the payment of all
monies received by such officer according to the laws of the City; provided,
however, that the City Treasurer's bond shall be in such amount as may be set
by resolution or ordinance, but not less than that established by the State
Money Management Council. The form and proof of the required bond or insurance
shall be approved by the City Administrator and shall be filed and maintained
with the City Recorder. The premium charged by a corporate surety for any
official bond shall be paid by the City. (Ord. 2019-7, 4-16-2019)
1-10-5: SALARIES; GENERALLY:
The elective and appointive officers of the City shall receive such
compensation for their services as the City Council may fix by ordinance
adopting compensation or compensation schedules enacted after public hearing,
or as enacted by Utah Code Annotated section 10-3-818, as amended. (Ord. 2017-
47, 11-14-2017)
1-10-6: REVIEW OF SALARIES; PUBLIC HEARING:
   A.   Authority: Upon its own motion, the City Council may review or consider
the compensation of any elective or appointive officer of the City for the
purpose of determining whether or not it should be adopted, changed or amended.
In the event that the City Council decides that such compensation or
compensation schedules should be adopted, changed or amended, it shall set a
time and place for a public hearing at which all interested persons shall be
given an opportunity to be heard.
   B.   Notice Requirements: Notice of the time, place and purpose of the
meeting shall be published at least seven (7) days prior thereto by publication
in at least one issue of a newspaper published in the County within which the
City is situated and generally circulated in the City, if there is one;
otherwise, by posting in three (3) public places within the City.
   C.   Ordinance Enacted: After the conclusion of the public hearing, the City
Council may enact an ordinance fixing, changing or amending the compensation of
any elective or appointive officer of the City or adopting a compensation
schedule applicable to any officer.
   D.   Monthly Compensation: The compensation of all City officers shall be
paid at least monthly out of the Treasury. (Ord. 2017-47, 11-14-2017)
1-10-7: SALARIES OF ELECTIVE OFFICERS:
   A.   Established: Salaries of the elected officials of the City shall be
paid monthly as follows:
      1.   Mayor: One thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00).
      2.   Council member: Six hundred dollars ($600.00).
   B.   Schedule: The salaries of this section shall be paid according to the
established payroll schedule of the City, which shall not be less than once per
month. (Ord. 2017-47, 11-14-2017)
1-10-8: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The duties, powers and privileges of all officers in any way connected with the
City government not defined in this title shall be defined by the City Council,
and the defining by this title of the duties of City officers shall not
preclude the City Council from further defining any additional duties to be
performed by any such officer. (Ord. 2017-47, 11-14-2017)
1-10-9: DELIVERY OF PROPERTY TO SUCCESSOR:
If any person, having been an officer of the City, shall not within five (5)
days after notification and request deliver to his successor office all
property, papers and effects of every description in his possession belonging
to the City, or pertaining to the office held, he or she shall be guilty of a
Class C misdemeanor and upon conviction, subject to penalty as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this title. (Ord. 2017-47, 11-14-2017)
CHAPTER 11
GOVERNMENT STRUCTURE
SECTION:
1-11-1: City Administrator
1-11-2: City Organization Specified
1-11-3: Organizational Chart
1-11-4: Departments And Directors
1-11-4-1:    Public Safety Department
1-11-4-2:    Community Development Department
1-11-4-3:    Parks And Recreation Department
1-11-4-4:    Library And Arts Department
1-11-4-5:    Legal Department
1-11-4-6:    Engineering Department
1-11-4-7:    Public Works Department
1-11-5: Authority And Duties Of Other Officers
1-11-5-1:    City Recorder
1-11-5-2:    City Treasurer
1-11-5-3:    Justice Of The Peace
1-11-1: CITY ADMINISTRATOR:
   A.   Appointment 1 : The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city
council, may appoint a city administrator to exercise the duties prescribed
herein which are consistent with state law. The city administrator shall be
appointed on the basis of ability and prior experience in the field of public
administration, together with such other qualifications as may be prescribed.
The city administrator may be removed by the mayor with the advice and consent
of the city council. Except as the mayor may otherwise direct, and except as
otherwise provided in this section, the city administrator may exercise the
administrative powers of the city, including the signing of contracts. (Ord.
2002-5, 2-5-2002; amd. 2003 Code)
   B.   Powers And Duties: The city administrator's powers and duties may
include, but are not limited to, the following, insofar as the mayor directs in
each case:
      1.   Supervising the administration and enforcement of all laws, this
code, and other ordinances of the city as they affect the city departments;
      2.   Executing the policies affecting the city departments that are
adopted by the city council;
      3.   Recommending to the mayor the hiring, discipline or termination of
department directors appointed by the mayor;
      4.   Conducting performance evaluations and recommending pay adjustments
for department directors as prescribed by this code, other city ordinances or
policy;
      5.   Coordinating all divisions of the city through the offices of the
department directors;
      6.   Holding periodic staff meetings with the directors and other
officers and officials;
      7.   Authorizing the issuance of such administrative rules and
regulations, and establishing general administrative procedures which are not
in conflict with the laws of the state, this code or other city ordinances;
      8.   Attending all official city council meetings;
      9.   Establishing policies and procedures for the city's procurement
process;
      10.   Chairing various coordinating committees that consider multi-
departmental issues;
      11.   Coordinating the writing and administration of government grants;
      12.   Functioning as a director of any of the other departments of the
city, if assigned by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council;
and
      13.   Performing such other duties as may be prescribed by the mayor or
city council as permitted by law, by this code, or by other city ordinance.
(Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection 1-10-2A of this title.
1-11-2: CITY ORGANIZATION SPECIFIED:
   A.   Departments And Department Heads: The organization of the City shall
consist of eight (8) departments and their respective department heads, as
follows:
      1.   Public Safety Department, with a Police Chief and a Fire Chief;
      2.   Community Development Department, with a Community Development
Director;
      3.   Legal Department, with a City Attorney;
      4.   Finance Department, with a Finance Director;
      5.   Engineering Department, with a City Engineer;
      6.   Parks and Recreation Department, with a Parks and Recreation
Director;
      7.   Library and Arts Department, with a Library and Arts Director; and
      8.   Public Works Department, with a Public Works Director.
   B.   Organization Included Within Established Departments: All
organizational elements of the City, including commissions, boards, councils,
agencies, offices and committees, along with contract, temporary, part time and
full time employees and volunteers, will be included within one of these eight
(8) departments. (Ord. 2014-32, 8-19-2014)
1-11-3: ORGANIZATIONAL CHART:
The City Council may adopt by resolution an organizational chart setting forth
the division of authority and providing for the administration of the various
departments, commissions, boards and committees of the City. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-
2002)
1-11-4: DEPARTMENTS AND DIRECTORS:
1-11-4-1: PUBLIC SAFETY DEPARTMENT:
This department administers all of the divisions and commissions related to the
health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the City, including the Police
Department, Fire Department, ambulance and first response services and
emergency planning services.
   A.   Chiefs Appointed: The Police Chief and Fire Chief are appointed
positions.
   B.   Functions Of Chief: The functions of each respective Chief are as
follows:
      1.   Performs managerial duties and plans, organizes, coordinates and
supervises all phases of their respective departments including police
protection, fire protection, emergency planning and preparation, ambulance and
first response.
      2.   Coordinates administrative matters with directors of other
departments.
      3.   Organizes and provides support for periodic coordination of a public
safety meeting.
      4.   Recommends strategic direction for the Department of Public Safety
to the Mayor, City Council and City Administrator.
      5.   Participates on and provides administrative and technical support to
the Disaster Preparedness Committee.
      6.   Attends and provides support for City Council meetings and work
sessions as required.
   C.   Organization Chart: The elements of this department and those other
City organizations to which this department shall give support shall be as
outlined on the City organization chart. (Ord. 2014-3, 1-7-2014)
1-11-4-2: COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DEPARTMENT:
The role of the Community Development Department is to support the legislative
process in the orderly maintenance and development of residential, commercial
and industrial uses within the City in compliance with the General Plan and
zoning ordinances.
   A.   Director Appointed: The Director is an appointed position. (Ord. 2014-
3, 1-7-2014)
   B.   Functions Of Director: The Director's functions are as follows:
      1.   Performs managerial duties and plans, organizes, coordinates and
supervises community development, zoning, inspection, land use, and all phases
of implementing the City General Plan.
      2.   Coordinates administrative efforts with Directors of other
departments.
      3.   Recommends strategic direction for the department to the Mayor, City
Council and City Administrator.
      4.   Participates with and provides administrative and technical support
to the Planning Commission, Hearings Officer, Design Review Board, Neighborhood
Advisory Board and Downtown Advisory Board.
      5.   Attends and provides support for City Council meetings and work
sessions as required. (Ord. 2017-29, 5-16-2017)
   C.   Organization Chart: The elements of this department and those other
City organizations to which this department shall give support shall be as
outlined on the City organization chart.
   D.   Responsibilities Of Director: The Community Development Director shall
be responsible for the following:
      1.   Planning Department: The City Planner is responsible for data
gathering, evaluation, analysis of development plans, and projection of future
patterns of development within the community on a comprehensive basis.
      2.   Zoning And Code Enforcement: The Community Development Director and
assigned staff coordinate zoning and Code enforcement activities with the
Police Department, and assist in interpreting the City zoning ordinances when
interpretation is necessary. Coordination with the Police Department includes
the enforcement of the following City codes: zoning (title 10 of this Code);
weeds (title 4, chapter 4 of this Code); and business licenses and regulations
(title 3 of this Code).
      3.   Building Department: The chief building official is responsible for
enforcement of all applicable codes for residential, commercial and industrial
structures within the City.
      4.   Construction Inspection Department: The construction inspector is
responsible for assuring compliance with the approved plans and specifications
for all subdivisions, commercial site improvements, industrial site
improvements and public works projects. (Ord. 2014-3, 1-7-2014)
1-11-4-3: PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT:
The role of the Parks and Recreation Department is to provide various
activities and venues which create the opportunity for wholesome physical,
mental, recreational, and educational opportunities for the citizens of the
City.
   A.   Responsibilities Of Director: The Parks and Recreation Department
Director shall be responsible for the following departments:
      1.   Parks Division: The Parks Division is responsible for providing safe
and enjoyable areas for members of the community to use in recreation and
enjoyment of the outdoors, and to make City owned properties aesthetically
pleasing.
      2.   Cemetery Division: The Cemetery Division is responsible for
providing services pertaining to burials, recordkeeping, planning and
maintaining the cemetery grounds in a manner that is safe and aesthetically
pleasing.
      3.   Pleasant Grove City Recreation: The Recreation Department shall
provide programs, services and facilities that enrich the lives of community
residents.
      4.   Veterans Memorial Pool: Veterans Memorial Pool is responsible for
providing a safe and enjoyable aquatic environment for the members of the
community.
      5.   Senior Citizen Center: The Senior Citizen Center serves the
individual needs of the City's senior population without discrimination,
targeting the areas of nutrition and social interaction.
      6.   Facilities Division: The Facilities Division is responsible for
maintaining City owned building and amenities. Creating a safe environment to
work, recreate and enjoy the outdoors.
      7.   Custodial Division: The Custodial Division is responsible for
providing cleaning services for City owned facilities. Creating clean and safe
facilities for employees, patrons, and citizens.
   B.   Director Appointed: The director is an appointed position.
   C.   Functions Of Director: The director's functions are as follows:
      1.   Performs managerial duties and plans, organizes, coordinates and
supervises all work and activities in relation to parks, recreation, aquatics,
cemetery, city celebrations and special events.
      2.   Coordinates administrative efforts with directors of other
departments.
      3.   Recommends strategic direction for the department to the mayor, city
council and city administrator.
      4.   Attends and provides support for city council meetings and work
sessions as required.
      5.   Participates with and provides administrative and technical support
to the Pleasant Grove beautification and shade tree advisory commission and
recreation advisory committee.
   D.   Organization Chart: The elements of this department and those other
city organizations to which this department shall give support shall be as
outlined on the city organization chart. (Ord. 2014-3, 1-7-2014)
1-11-4-4: LIBRARY AND ARTS DEPARTMENT:
The role of this department is to provide various activities, special events,
facilities and venues which create the opportunity for wholesome, educational
and cultural opportunities for the citizens of the city.
   A.   Functions Of Director: The library and arts department director's
functions shall be as follows:
      1.   Performs managerial duties and plans, organizes, coordinates and
supervises all work and activities in relation to the city library, arts
commission, historical commission, city celebrations and special events.
      2.   Coordinates administrative efforts with directors of other
departments.
      3.   Recommends strategic direction for the department to the mayor, city
council and city administrator.
      4.   Attends and provides support for city council meetings and work
sessions as required.
   B.   Responsibilities Of Director: The library and arts director is an
appointed position and will be responsible for the following facilities,
activities, boards and commissions:
      1.   Pleasant Grove City Library: The library shall provide all residents
of the city with equal and adequate access to informational resources, and
shall provide diverse, accessible materials, services and programs for the
education, information, enrichment and entertainment of all citizens of the
community.
      2.   Arts Commission: The library and arts director shall provide
supervision and support to the Utah Children's Choir, PG Players, Center Stage,
concerts in the park, PG orchestra and visual arts activities.
      3.   Historical Commission: Historical commission.
      4.   City Events: Memorial Day, Strawberry Days, Heritage Festival,
Veterans Day, tree lighting, and Christmas holiday activities.
   C.   Organization Chart: The elements of this department and those other
city organizations to which this department shall give support shall be as
outlined on the city organization chart. (Ord. 2014-32, 8-19-2014)
1-11-4-5: LEGAL DEPARTMENT:
The city attorney is responsible for the criminal prosecution of infraction and
misdemeanor violations of local, county, and state laws that occur within the
city boundaries, coordinates city's participation in defense of civil lawsuits,
resolves conflicts, drafts ordinances and agreements, interacts with citizens,
provides legal advice and counsel to the mayor, city council and department
heads, and assists all other departments in fulfilling their responsibilities.
   A.   Appointed Position: The city attorney is an appointed position.
   B.   Licensed In Utah: The city attorney must be a graduate of an accredited
law school, and licensed to practice law in the state of Utah.
   C.   Organization Chart: The elements of this department and those other
city organizations to which this department shall give support shall be as
outlined on the city organization chart. (Ord. 2014-3, 1-7-2014)
1-11-4-6: ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT:
The city engineer is responsible for evaluation and approval of development
plans for subdivisions, commercial and industrial projects, and public
improvements, such as transportation systems and drainage systems. The city
engineer also serves as the construction engineer when the inspection
department does not have a construction engineer.
   A.   Appointed Position: The city engineer is an appointed position.
   B.   Registered: The city engineer must be a registered professional
engineer under title 58, chapter 22, professional engineers and professional
land surveyors licensing act of the Utah code.
   C.   Organization Chart: The elements of this department and those other
city organizations to which this department shall give support shall be as
outlined on the city organization chart. (Ord. 2014-3, 1-7-2014)
1-11-4-7: PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT:
The public works department is responsible for overseeing and managing the city
utilities including the culinary water system, pressurized irrigation water
system, storm drain, sewer, and streets.
   A.   Director Appointed: The director is an appointed position.
   B.   Functions Of Director: The director's functions are as follows:
      1.   Responsible for daily planning, organizing, and ensuring execution
of staff projects and activities involving the maintenance of city vehicles,
storm drains, streets and water and sewer infrastructure.
      2.   Coordinates administrative efforts with directors of other
departments.
      3.   Recommends strategic direction for the department to the mayor, city
council and city administrator.
      4.   Plans and administers the department budget.
      5.   Attends and provides support for city council meetings and work
sessions as required.
   C.   Responsibilities Of Director: The public works director will be
responsible for the following facilities, activities, boards and commissions:
      1.   Member of the neighborhood advisory committee.
      2.   Member of the design review board.
      3.   Member of the design review committee.
      4.   Member of the Pleasant Grove metropolitan water board.
      5.   Responsible for pump stations, water tanks, streets, and all of the
attendant infrastructure that makes up the municipal utility system.
   D.   Water And Sewer Department: The duties of this department include:
operate and maintain the infrastructure and systems for the culinary and
secondary water systems and sanitary sewer system.
Water, sewer and culinary departments have one superintendent who reports to
the public works director.
   E.   Streets And Storm Drain Department: The duties of this department
include: operate and maintain the road system; inspect, operate, and maintain
the storm drain system and oversee the development projects that include city
infrastructure; and all replacement of existing infrastructure and installation
of expansions to the system. This department has one superintendent that
reports to the public works director.
   F.   Organization Chart: The elements of this department and those other
city organizations to which this department shall give support shall be as
outlined on the city organization chart. (Ord. 2014-32, 8-19-2014)
1-11-5: AUTHORITY AND DUTIES OF OTHER OFFICERS:
1-11-5-1: CITY RECORDER:
   A.   Appointment 1 : The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city
council, shall appoint a qualified person to the office of city recorder, who
shall have such powers and perform such duties as are now or may hereafter be
provided by law, this code or other ordinance.
   B.   Duties Specified: The duties of the city recorder are as follows:
      1.   The city recorder shall keep the corporate seal, attest and seal all
legal documents as required by law or this code, and countersign and maintain a
properly indexed record of all contracts entered into by the city.
      2.   The city recorder or deputy shall attend the meetings of the city
council and keep the record of the proceedings thereof in a book or books to be
kept for that purpose, and shall further keep a separate book for minutes of
the proceedings of the city council, which records shall at all times be open
to public inspection.
      3.   The city recorder's office shall be kept at the place of meeting of
the city council or at some other place convenient thereto, as the council may
direct. Copies of all papers filed in the city recorder's office and
transcripts from all records of the city council, certified by the city
recorder under the corporate seal, shall be evidence in all courts as if the
originals thereof were produced.
      4.   The city recorder or deputy shall record, in the order of date
passed, all ordinances, orders and resolutions passed by the city council in a
book or books to be kept for that purpose.
      5.   The city recorder shall prepare for publication all ordinance titles
and notices as assigned or required by law or by this code, and shall cause
them to be published or posted as required by law or this code.
      6.   The city recorder shall keep records containing the names of all
persons elected or appointed to any office in the city; the dates of their
elections or appointments; the terms of office; the dates of deaths,
resignations or removals of any such officer; and the names of persons
appointed to fill any vacancies so created.
      7.   The city recorder shall, under the direction of the administration,
maintain a records access and management program as set forth under state law
or this code.
      8.   The city recorder, as the election officer, shall administer
municipal elections as authorized by Utah Code Annotated title 20A et seq., as
amended.
      9.   The city recorder shall pay into the treasury all monies belonging
to the city coming into the recorder's hands by virtue of the recorder's
office, and shall deliver to his or her successor in office the corporate seal,
together with all books, papers, records and other property in the recorder's
possession belonging to the city.
      10.   The city recorder shall keep a list of all property coming into his
or her possession from the predecessor in office, and by purchase during his or
her term, and shall deliver the list, together with the property, to the
successor in office.
      11.   The city recorder shall certify the ordinance or resolution setting
the tax levy to the county auditor before June 15 of each year.
      12.   After the legislative body accepts an annexation petition, the city
recorder shall certify the legal sufficiency of the petition to the legislative
body within thirty (30) days after the annexation petition is accepted.
   C.   Warrants: In the event the city is without funds on deposit in one of
its appropriate bank accounts with which to pay any lawfully approved claim,
the city recorder shall draw and sign a warrant upon the city treasurer for
payment of the claim, the warrant to be tendered to the payee named thereon.
   D.   Payment Of Claims:
      1.   The city recorder or designee shall maintain the general books for
each fund of the city and all subsidiary records relating thereto, including a
list of the outstanding bonds, their purpose, amount, terms, and date and place
payable.
      2.   The city recorder or designee shall keep accounts with all receiving
and disbursing officers of the city, shall preaudit all claims and demands
against the city before they are allowed, and shall prepare the necessary
checks in payment. Such checks shall include an appropriate certification
pursuant to Utah Code Annotation section
11-1-1, as amended, examples of which shall be presented in the uniform
accounting manual for Utah cities. The city recorder shall also certify on the
voucher or check copy, as appropriate, that:
         a.   The claim has been preaudited and documented;
         b.   The claim has been approved in one of the following ways:
            (1)   Purchase order directly approved by the city council or its
delegate;
            (2)   Claim directly approved by the City Council; or
            (3)   Claim approved by the Financial Officer; and
         c.   The claim is within the lawful debt limit of the City; and
         d.   The claim does not overexpend the appropriate departmental budget
established by the City Council. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
   E.   Recording Of Ordinances:
      1.   The City Recorder shall keep and file a copy of each ordinance
hereafter passed by order of the City Council and shall maintain copies of City
ordinances showing all amendments and additions, and copies of those ordinances
repealed; the City Recorder shall further place a copy of each such amendment,
addition or repealed ordinance in the proper section of the copies of City
ordinances provided to the Mayor and Council members. As portions of this Code
are replaced and/or deleted by legislative action, it shall be the
responsibility of the City Recorder to delete that portion from the current
Code.
      2.   It shall be the duty of the City Recorder to send a copy of all
ordinances, amendments, additions and repeals to the Chairperson of the
following permanent committees: the Planning Commission, and to each of the
heads of the City departments identified in section
1-11-2 of this chapter. (Ord. 2017-29, 5-16-2017)
   F.   Financial Statements: The City Recorder or designee shall cause to be
prepared and presented to the City Council the following financial statements:
      1.   At the end of each month, a summary of cash receipts and
disbursements by fund or appropriate groups of funds, showing in total the
beginning cash and invested balances, the receipts and disbursements separately
for the period, and cash and invested balances in each fund or group of funds
at the end of the period.
      2.   At the end of such periods as the City Council may direct, but not
less often than once each quarter, a statement of revenues and expenditures and
comparison with the budget of the General Fund, including a comparison of
actual expenditures for the period with the allotments pertaining thereto.
      3.   A monthly statement of income and expense of each utility fund,
reflecting operations to date in the current year and a comparison thereof with
operating results for the same period during the preceding year.
      4.   At the end of such periods as the City Council may require, a
condensed statement of receipts and disbursements and comparison with the cash
budget of each utility fund, including a comparison of actual disbursements for
the period with allotments pertaining thereto.
      5.   Such statements of operations in other special funds or reports on
financial condition, at such times as the City Council may require.
   G.   Annual Financial Report: Within one hundred eighty (180) days after the
close of each fiscal year, the City Recorder or designee shall present to the
City Council an annual financial report prepared in conformity with generally
accepted accounting principles, as prescribed in the Uniform Accounting Manual
for Utah Cities. This requirement may be satisfied by presentation of the audit
report furnished by the independent auditor, if the financial statements
included are appropriately prepared and reviewed with the City Council. Copies
of the annual financial report or the audit report furnished by the independent
auditor shall be filed with the State auditor and shall be filed as a public
document in the Office of the City Recorder.
   H.   Notice Of Audit Availability: Within ten (10) days following the
receipt of the audit report furnished by the independent auditor, the City
Recorder shall prepare and publish at least twice in a newspaper of general
circulation published within the County a notice to the public that the audit
of the City has been completed and a copy thereof may be inspected at the
Office of the City Recorder.
   I.   Ex Officio Auditor: The City Recorder is also the ex officio City
Auditor and performs the duties of that office.
   J.   Appeals Board: When an appeal is taken by a terminated employee, the
employee files a written notice of appeal with the City Recorder within ten
(10) days after the employment action. Upon the filing of the appeal, the City
Recorder is to refer a copy of the appeal to the Appeal Board. (See Utah Code
Annotated section 10-3-1106, as amended.)
   K.   Budget Duties:
      1.   When a tentative budget is adopted by the governing body, all
supporting schedules and data shall be a public record and shall be available
for inspection in the office of the city recorder for a period of at least ten
(10) days prior to the adoption of a final budget. (See Utah Code Annotated
section 10-6-112, as amended.)
      2.   Upon final budget adoption, a certified copy of the adopted budget
is filed in the office of the city recorder and shall be available to the
public for inspection during regular business hours. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection 1-10-2A of this title.
1-11-5-2: CITY TREASURER:
   A.   Duties: The city treasurer shall be custodian of all money, bonds or
other securities belonging to the city. The city treasurer shall receive all
money payable to the city, including all taxes, licenses and fines, and shall
keep an accurate detailed account thereof in the manner provided in this
chapter or as the city council may from time to time direct by ordinance or
resolution. The city treasurer shall collect all special taxes and assessments
as provided by law and ordinance.
   B.   Signing Checks: The city treasurer or such other person as the city
council may designate by resolution shall sign all checks. Prior to affixing
the signatures, the city treasurer or such other person shall determine that
sufficient funds are on deposit in the appropriate bank account of the city to
honor such check. The city treasurer shall make provision for payment of all
warrants issued before signing any subsequently issued checks.
   C.   Warrants: The city treasurer shall pay all warrants in the order in
which presented and as money becomes available for payment thereof in the
appropriate funds of the city. The city treasurer shall note upon the back of
each warrant presented to him the date of presentation and the date of payment.
   D.   Receipts: The city treasurer shall give or cause to be given to every
person paying money to the treasury a receipt or other evidence of payment
therefor, specifying the date of payment and upon what account paid, and shall
file the duplicate of such receipt or other evidence of payment in the office
of the city recorder.
   E.   Care Or Misuse Of Funds: The city treasurer shall keep all money
belonging to the city separate and distinct from his or her own money and shall
promptly make deposit thereof in the appropriate bank accounts of the city.
Whenever it shall appear to the city council that the city treasurer is making
profit out of public money or is using the same for any purpose not authorized
by law, such treasurer or officer shall be suspended from office. Upon a
conviction for such offense, the office shall become vacant.
   F.   Financial Reports: The city treasurer or designee shall report to the
city council at such times as may be prescribed by it, giving a full and
detailed account of receipts and expenditures since the last report, along with
an account of the condition of the treasury. The city treasurer shall also keep
a registry of all warrants redeemed and paid, and the person to whom paid,
specifying also the time of payment. All such warrants shall be examined by the
city council at the time of making such report.
   G.   Special Assessments: All money received by the city treasurer on any
special assessment shall be applied to the payment of the improvement for which
the assessment was made. Such money shall be used for the payment of interest
and principal on bonds or other indebtedness issued in settlement thereof, and
shall be used for no other purpose whatsoever except as otherwise provided by
law. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
1-11-5-3: JUSTICE OF THE PEACE:
   A.   Appointment: A justice of the peace shall be appointed to terms of four
(4) years beginning the first Monday in February 1988, which appointment shall
be made by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the city council. The justice
of the peace may be removed from office in the same manner as established by
state law for the removal of county justices.
   B.   Vacancy; Disqualification:
      1.   If a vacancy occurs in the office of the justice of the peace, the
mayor shall, with the consent of the city council, fill the vacancy by
appointment for the unexpired term. The person appointed shall qualify in the
same manner as a municipal justice, and has and shall exercise all the
authority of the municipal justice.
      2.   If a municipal justice is unable or disqualified to perform the
duties of his office, or is absent, the mayor shall appoint another justice of
the peace residing within the county to act as the temporary municipal justice
of the peace. The temporarily appointed justice has and shall discharge the
duties of the municipal justice, but only during the disability or absence of
the municipal justice.
   C.   Duties: The justice of the peace shall perform the duties required of
him by law and by the provisions of this code, and shall have all powers
conferred upon him by the state.
   D.   Report: The justice of the peace shall report to the city council from
time to time, as it shall direct, the number of cases brought before him on
behalf of the city, the amount of fines levied, the amount collected and such
other pertinent facts as may be required by the city council. The justice of
the peace, or designee, shall pay all fines, fees, forfeitures or any other
sums collected by the justice of the peace to the city treasurer within seven
(7) days of receipt. (Ord. 2002-5, 2-5-2002)
CHAPTER 12
REVENUE AND FINANCE
SECTION:
1-12-1: Approval Of Claims
1-12-2: Franchises
1-12-1: APPROVAL OF CLAIMS:
It shall be the duty of the city council to carefully examine all claims
presented against the city when properly verified, and such of them as are
found to be valid obligations of the city shall be approved and ordered paid.
(1990 Code § 3.04.010; amd. 2003 Code)
1-12-2: FRANCHISES:
   A.   Application; Copies; Fee: Whenever application is made to the city
council for a franchise or grant of special privilege, or for an extension or
renewal of any existing franchise or for a grant of special privilege, the
applicant shall pay into the treasury a fee to be determined by the city
council. (1990 Code § 3.08.010; amd. 2003 Code)
   B.   Franchises Nonassignable; Exception: All franchises and grants of
special privilege shall be deemed to be nonassignable without the express
permission of the city council, whether such limitation is set forth in the
body of the franchise or grant or not. (1990 Code § 3.08.020)
   C.   Manner Of Assignment: All assignments of franchises and special grants
must be in writing and a copy thereof filed in the office of the city recorder
before any such assignment or transfer will be recognized by the city. (1990
Code § 3.08.030)
   D.   Forfeiture: Any attempted assignment or transfer of a franchise or a
special privilege, not made in accordance with the provisions of this section,
shall operate as a forfeiture of all rights of the grantee therein given. (1990
Code § 3.08.040)
CHAPTER 13
CONSTITUTIONAL TAKING ISSUES
SECTION:
1-13-1: Policy Considerations
1-13-2: Defined
1-13-3: Guidelines Advisory
1-13-4: Review Of Decision
1-13-5: Reviewing Guidelines
1-13-6: Results Of Review
1-13-1: POLICY CONSIDERATIONS:
There is an underlying policy in the city strongly favoring the careful
consideration of matters involving constitutional taking claims, in fairness to
the owner of private property bringing the claim and in view of the uncertainty
and expense involved in defending lawsuits alleging such issues. At the same
time, the legitimate role of government in lawfully regulating real property
must be preserved and the public's right to require the dedication or exaction
of property consistent with the constitution. Consistent with this policy, it
is desired that a procedure be established for the review of actions that may
involve the issue of a constitutional taking. These provisions are to assist
city government in considering decisions that may involve constitutional
takings. It is intended that a procedure for such a review be provided, as well
