10-20-12: NUISANCE; VIOLATION; PENALTY:
   A.   Any person who shall be found to be maintaining a nuisance as stated in
section
10-20-11 of this chapter shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor and upon
conviction, subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code)
   B.   In the event that the city or other interested party elects to seek
redress by civil action instead of by filing of a criminal complaint, the owner
of any building constituting a "nuisance", as defined above, shall be subject
to forfeiture of the bond to pay damages to the person or persons injured by
the owner's maintenance of a nuisance and his failure to abate said nuisance.
(Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
10-20-13: DENIAL OF PERMIT:
The building inspector shall refuse to issue a permit if he finds:
   A.   The building is too large to move without endangering persons or
property in the city;
   B.   Any application requirement or any fee or deposit requirement has not
been complied with;
   C.   The building is in such a state of deterioration or disrepair or is
otherwise so structurally unsafe that it could not be moved without endangering
persons and property in the city;
   D.   The building is structurally unsafe or unfit for the purpose for which
moved, if the removed location is in the city;
   E.   The applicant's equipment is unsafe and persons and property would be
endangered by its use;
   F.   Zoning or other ordinances would be violated by the building in its new
location;
   G.   For any other reason, persons or property in the city would be
endangered by the moving of the building;
   H.   The owner of the building to be moved has failed or refused to file a
proper performance bond as required under section
10-20-10 of this chapter. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
10-20-14: STREETS TO BE DESIGNATED FOR TRAVEL:
The building inspector shall procure from the department of public works a list
of designated streets over which the building may be moved. The building
inspector shall have the list approved by the chief of police and shall
reproduce the list upon the permit in writing. In making their determination,
the department of public works and the chief of police shall act to assure
maximum safety to persons and property in the city and to minimize congestion
and traffic hazards on public streets. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
10-20-15: REQUIREMENTS OF PERMITTEE:
Every permittee under this chapter shall:
   A.   Use Designated Streets: Move a building only over streets designated
for such use in the written permit.
   B.   Notify Of Revised Moving Time: Notify the building inspector of a
desired change in moving date and hours as proposed in the application.
   C.   Notify Of Damage: Notify the building official in writing of any and
all damage done to property belonging to the city or persons in the city within
twenty four (24) hours after the damage or injury has occurred.
   D.   Display Lights: Cause red lights to be displayed during the nighttime
on every side of the building while moving along or standing on a street in
such manner as to warn the public of the obstruction, and shall at all times
erect and maintain barricades across the streets in such manner as to protect
the public from damage or injury by reason of the removal of the building.
   E.   Street Occupancy Period: Remove the building from the city streets
after four (4) days of such occupancy, unless an extension is granted by the
city council.
   F.   Comply With Governing Law: Comply with the building code, the fire
code, the zoning ordinance and all other applicable ordinances and laws upon
relocating the building in the city.
   G.   Pay Expense Of Officer: Pay the expense of any traffic officer ordered
by the building official to accompany the movement of the building to protect
the public from injury.
   H.   Clear Old Premises: Remove all rubbish and materials, and fill all
excavations to existing grade at the original building site so that the
premises are left in a safe and sanitary condition, except that the filling of
any excavation on the premises to grade will not be required if a building
permit is issued for new construction on the premises within a reasonable
length of time as determined by the city building official. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-
18-2000)
10-20-16: ENFORCEMENT OF AUTHORITY:
The building official, the police department and the department of public works
shall enforce and carry out the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-
18-2000)
10-20-17: RECOVERY OF EXCESSIVE AMOUNTS:
The permittee shall be liable for any expenses, damages or costs in excess of
deposited amounts or securities, and the city attorney shall prosecute an
action against the permittee in a court of competent jurisdiction for the
recovery of such excessive amounts. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
10-20-18: ORIGINAL PREMISES LEFT IN UNSAFE CONDITION:
Where the permittee does not comply with the requirements of this chapter, the
city shall proceed to do the necessary work to leave the original premises in a
safe and sanitary condition. The cost of such work shall be charged against the
general cash deposit required by section
10-20-10 of this chapter. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
10-20-19: INSPECTION OF WORK:
The cash deposit or check shall not be released or the bond shall not be
exonerated as the case may be, nor shall the removed building be occupied until
the community development director certifies that all work and improvements
specified by the planning commission and this title have been satisfactorily
completed. The planning commission shall cause an inspection of the building at
its new location to be made on request of the owner or applicant, or at the
expiration of the time designated by the planning commission for completion of
the work. Said inspection shall include a determination of compliance with
provisions of the applicable codes and conditions or requirements imposed by
the planning commission upon approval of the building relocation. No
certificates of occupancy or certificates of zoning compliance shall be issued
until the inspection has been made and all code requirements and conditions
complied with. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
10-20-20: OTHER PERMITS REQUIRED:
Approval or conditional approval by the planning commission hereunder is not a
building permit, and shall not relieve the applicant of requirements for
obtaining necessary building permits and moving permits. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-
2000)
CHAPTER 21
HOME OCCUPATIONS 1
SECTION:
10-21-1: Purpose And Intent
10-21-2: Home Occupation Permit Required
10-21-3: Procedure
10-21-4: Conditions
10-21-5: Minor Home Occupations
10-21-6: Major Home Occupations
10-21-7: Noncompliance
10-21-8: Appeal
10-21-9: Business License Required
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection 3-1-5A4 of this code.
10-21-1: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
The purpose and intent of this chapter is to encourage the majority of business
activities to be conducted in appropriate commercial zones. Business activities
may be conducted within a residence on a limited basis, if such activities
comply with the standards of this section. All home occupations shall be
secondary and incidental to the residential use. The use should be conducted so
that neighbors, under normal conditions, would not be aware of its existence.
Home occupations are a temporary privilege which can be revoked if disruption
of the residential neighborhood occurs. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003
Code; amd. Ord. 2019-24, 12-3-2019)
10-21-2: HOME OCCUPATION PERMIT REQUIRED:
To assure compliance with provisions of this title and to protect the character
of residential neighborhoods in the City, a home occupation permit shall be
obtained from the community development department before a dwelling unit in a
residential zone may be used for business purposes. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000;
amd. Ord. 2019-24, 12-3-2019)
10-21-3: PROCEDURE:
The community development director may, upon application, issue a home
occupation permit which shall state the home occupation permitted, the
conditions attached thereto, and any time limitations imposed thereon. The
permit shall not be issued unless the community development director is
satisfied that the applicant will meet all of the conditions listed in section
10-21-4 of this chapter, and that the applicant has agreed in writing to comply
with all said conditions. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. Ord. 2019-24, 12-3-
2019)
10-21-4: CONDITIONS:
Each and every one of the following conditions must be observed at all times by
the holder of a home occupation permit:
   A.   Employees Must Be Residents: Persons who are not bona fide residents of
the premises shall not be employed on said premises.
   B.   Conducted Within Structure: The home occupation shall be conducted
wholly within the structure on the premises and shall not exceed twenty five
percent (25%) of the total floor area of said structures. The home occupation
shall not occupy any area within the garage, unless the garage still functions
for parking, and as long as two (2) parking spaces for residential use are
still available.
   C.   Number Of Meetings: Promotional meetings for the purpose of selling
merchandise, taking orders or training shall not be held more than once per
month.
   D.   Sales: The home occupation may include the sale of commodities.
However, it is the intent that it be limited to items produced on the premises,
or items that are incidental to the service provided, e.g., a beautician who
also sells hair care products to her clientele. The home occupation shall not
generate more than two (2) vehicular round trips related to the home occupation
business activities during any single hour, including deliveries and shipping.
      1.   Online Sales: Internet and mail-order-based sales home occupations
are allowed as a home office only. The in-person monetary transaction and/or
exchange of merchandise is not allowed in the home, on the premises, or in any
portion of a residential zone.
   E.   Signs And Advertising: No sign or advertising shall be displayed on the
premises, except nameplates not exceeding two (2) square feet in area.
   F.   Displays: No display of any kind shall be visible from the exterior of
the premises.
   G.   Yard And Similar Sales: Garage, basement, yard or other similar sales
shall not be allowed more than a total of five (5) days in any calendar year
(see subsection 10-16-2B of this title). Such sales do not constitute a home
occupation.
   H.   Vehicle Use And Storage; Deliveries: Only one vehicle may be used in
association with the home occupation and shall be garaged or stored entirely
within a building or structure. The vehicle used for the home occupation shall
be limited to a maximum size of one ton gross vehicle weight. No business shall
be permitted that requires receipt or delivery of merchandise, goods or
equipment by other than a passenger motor vehicle or by parcel or letter
carrier mail service using vehicles typically employed in residential
deliveries. No deliveries by semi-tractor/trailer truck are permitted.
   I.   Code Compliance: There shall be complete conformity with the City Code,
Dire, Building, Plumbing, Electrical and County Health Codes, and to all State,
County and City laws and ordinances.
   J.   Excessive Demand For Services: The home occupation shall not cause a
demand for Municipal or utility, services or community facilities in excess of
those usually and customarily provided for residential uses.
   K.   Alteration Of Residential Character: The home occupation shall not
alter the residential character of the premises or unreasonably disturb the
peace and quiet, including radio and television reception, of the neighborhood
by reason of color, design, materials, construction, lighting, sounds, noises
or vibrations.
   L.   Special Conditions Met: Any special condition established by the
Community Development Department and made of record in the home occupation
permit, as they deem necessary to carry out the intent of this section, shall
be met.
   M.   Term Of Permit; Renewal: All home occupation permits shall be valid for
one year, and may be renewed annually, provided there have been no reported
violations, complaints or detrimental characteristics which may, in the opinion
of the Planning Commission, require termination of said home occupation.
   N.   Handicapped Person: Handicapped persons can obtain a waiver of one or
more of these conditions through the Community Development Director to allow
such persons to become self-sufficient. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. Ord.
2019-24, 12-3-2019)
10-21-5: MINOR HOME OCCUPATIONS:
Home occupations which meet the above standards shall be defined as minor home
occupations. In order to minimize traffic and off street parking, and to avoid
health and sanitation risks from the disposal of medical wastes, medical,
dental and other health professional offices are specifically excluded as home
occupations. Permitted minor home occupations include, but are not necessarily
limited to, the following:
   A.   Artists, authors, architectural services, advertising.
   B.   Barber and beauty shops, including those that offer microblading
services as a cosmetic use, provided the number of clients is limited to one at
a time and that a permit from the Utah County Health Department is obtained
first.
   C.   Consulting services, craft sales.
   D.   Dance studio, aerobic exercise, music lessons, tutoring and general
educational instruction, provided the number of students is limited to two (2)
at a time.
   E.   Direct sales distribution, desktop publishing.
   F.   Data processing, computer programming, and service.
   G.   Family daycare (not more than six (6) children).
   H.   Home crafts.
   I.   Garden produce.
   J.   Janitorial services.
   K.   Insurance sales or broker, interior design.
   L.   Mail order.
   M.   Real estate sales, broker or appraiser.
   N.   Sales representative (home office only).
   O.   Contractors, provided there is no outside storage of equipment, and no
more than one company vehicle stored on site. (Ord. 2018-6, 2-6-2018; amd. Ord.
2019-24, 12-3-2019)
10-21-6: MAJOR HOME OCCUPATIONS:
"Major home occupations" are defined as home occupations which meet the
standards listed in section
10-21-4 of this chapter, as well as conditional use approval from the Planning
Commission. The Planning Commission may allow increases in intensity of a home
occupation, as follows:
   A.   The number of patrons or customers coming to the home may range up to
eight (8) per hour, provided sufficient off street parking is provided and the
use does not adversely affect the neighborhood. Daycare, preschools, and
nurseries, as defined in sections
10-6-2 and
10-15-27 of this title, are to be exempt from this subsection. Children that
are associated with any type of daycare, as defined in this Code, are not to be
considered as patrons or customers.
   B.   Employees not residing on the premises may be allowed during daytime
business hours (8:00 A.M. to 5:00 P.M.), subject to the following conditions:
      1.   No more than one nonresident employee is permitted for homes with
lots under twelve thousand (12,000) square feet, and two (2) nonresident
employees are permitted for homes with lots twelve thousand (12,000) square
feet or greater. Additional nonresident employees may be approved for homes
with lots twelve thousand (12,000) square feet or greater; however, the number
of additional employees shall not exceed the number of residents living in the
home, and may be subject to additional conditions as stated in subsection D of
this section.
      2.   Promotional meetings for the purpose of selling merchandise, taking
orders or training may be held one time per month.
      3.   On street parking shall not be allowed.
      4.   Multi-family residential home businesses shall not have a
nonresident employee.
   C.   An increase in the size and number of company vehicles and equipment
may be approved by the Planning Commission with appropriate mitigations, such
as fencing and buildings.
   D.   Additional conditions may be applied for visual appearance of site,
access improvements, noise limits, scope of services allowed, and other
conditions deemed necessary by the Planning Commission. (Ord. 2015-4, 1-27-
2015; amd. Ord. 2019-24, 12-3-2019)
10-21-7: NONCOMPLIANCE:
Any home occupation permit shall be revoked by the Planning Commission upon
violation of any requirements of this chapter, or upon failure to comply with
any of the conditions or limitations of the permit, unless such violation is
corrected within three (3) days of receipt of written notice thereof. A permit
may be revoked for repeated violations of the requirements of this chapter,
notwithstanding compliance to the violation notice. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000;
amd. Ord. 2019-24, 12-3-2019)
10-21-8: APPEAL:
In the event of denial of any permit, or of the revocation thereof, or of
objection to the limitations placed thereon, appeal may be made to the Hearings
Officer in accordance with the provisions of title 2, chapter 4 of this Code.
(Ord. 2017-29, 5-16-2017; amd. Ord. 2019-24, 12-3-2019)
10-21-9: BUSINESS LICENSE REQUIRED:
A home occupation permit is not a business license, and the granting of said
permit shall not relieve the permittee of any other license requirement of the
City or of any other public agency 1 . (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. Ord.
2019-24, 12-3-2019)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection 3-1-5A4 of this Code.
TITLE 11
LAND USE AND DEVELOPMENT
CHAPTER 1
ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
11-1-1: Development Review Committee Created
11-1-2: Scope
11-1-3: Procedures
11-1-4: Appeals
11-1-1: DEVELOPMENT REVIEW COMMITTEE CREATED:
   A.   In order to facilitate the process of plan consideration and approval,
there is hereby created a Development Review Committee (DRC) composed of the:
(Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code; Ord. 2004-19, 8-17-2004)
      1.   Community Development Director.
      2.   City Engineer.
      3.   City Water and Sewer Division Director. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000;
amd. 2003 Code)
      4.   Fire Chief. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code; Ord. 2004-19,
8-17-2004)
      5.   Street Division Director.
      6.   Building official.
      7.   Any other party having pertinent information, when requested by the
Community Development Director.
   B.   The first six (6) shall be considered as the designated members of the
committee. The Community Development Director will chair the committee. (Ord.
2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code)
11-1-2: SCOPE:
   A.   Essential Requirements: Any person, partnership, firm or corporation
wishing to construct developments in the City shall first make application for
a DRC meeting with the Community Development Department and pay the required
fee.
   B.   Large Scale Developments: The following are types of large scale
developments that are required to make application to the Planning Commission
and are required to attend a DRC meeting: (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003
Code; Ord. 2004-19, 8-17-2004)
      1.   All performance developments.
      2.   Planned subdivisions consisting of five (5) acres or more, or as
determined by staff.
      3.   Project plans with twenty (20) multiple-family units, commercial/
industrial developments with three (3) acres or more, or as determined by
staff. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code)
   C.   Other Developments Not Large Scale: Developments that are not large
scale, as classified above, may be reviewed and approved by the DRC. (Ord.
2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code; Ord. 2004-19, 8-17-2004)
11-1-3: PROCEDURES:
Administrative procedures for the DRC meeting shall be set forth by the
Community Development Department policy. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003
Code; Ord. 2004-19, 8-17-2004)
11-1-4: APPEALS:
Any person aggrieved by, or affected by any decision of the DRC may appeal the
decision to the Planning Commission. Any appeal from a decision by the Planning
Commission is made to the Hearings Officer as provided in title 2, chapter 4 of
this Code. (Ord. 2017-29, 5-16-2017)
CHAPTER 2
DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS; DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
11-2-1: General Development Standards
11-2-2: Policy Of Title Insurance
11-2-3: Phasing
11-2-4: Developable Land
11-2-5: Buildable Area
11-2-6: Saving Existing Vegetation
11-2-7: Definitions; Words, Terms, Phrases
11-2-8: Compliance With General Plan Policies
11-2-9: School Sites, Other Public Places
11-2-10: Construction And Maintenance Of Private Roads And Driveways By City
Prohibited
11-2-11: Work To Be Done By Engineer Or Surveyor
11-2-12: Dedication Of Water Rights Upon Development
11-2-13: Amendments May Be Required
11-2-14: Compliance With Final Plat
11-2-15: Clear Title To Property Required
11-2-1: GENERAL DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS:
The design of developments and subdivisions shall preserve, insofar as it is
possible, the natural terrain, natural drainage, existing topsoil, trees and
vegetation. Land which is subject to hazardous conditions such as landslides,
mudflows, rockfalls, snow avalanches, ground subsidence, shallow water table,
open quarries, floods, wetlands, and polluted water supply shall not be
subdivided until the hazards have been eliminated or evidence submitted that
the said hazards will be eliminated or mitigated by the development and
construction plans. All cut/fill slopes and other areas as determined by the
city engineer shall be reseeded or planted with vegetation. All developments as
required by section
11-3-5 of this title shall submit a traffic study. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-2-2: POLICY OF TITLE INSURANCE:
It is necessary to demonstrate a recent current policy of title insurance or a
preliminary title report showing that the persons listed as the owners in the
owner's dedication certificate on a plat or development have sufficient control
over the premises to effectually dedicate streets within the development where
required and to follow through with all other requirements of the city
ordinances. The parcel identification number assigned by the Utah County
recorder's office will be required with each application submitted for review
and approval. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-2-3: PHASING:
If the project is to be done in phases, the phasing must be completed in a
logical sequence, and in an orderly manner, without leapfrogging. A phasing
plan shall be provided by the developer for all projects done in phases. This
plan must be approved by the planning commission. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-2-4: DEVELOPABLE LAND:
Developable land is land under thirty percent (30%) slope which is capable of
being improved, subject to the sensitive lands ordinance (chapter 8 of this
title), with landscaping, buildings or parking. Land devoted to wetlands
preservation shall not be considered developable land, and must be subtracted
out of the total acreage before the density calculation is made, unless all or
a portion of the wetlands have been approved by the city council as usable
wetlands. When wetlands are not to be included as part of a lot, the wetland
will be required to be included on the plat as designated open space.
Exceptions: For those lots within the R-R or A-1 zone, wetlands may be included
as part of the lot, provided there is sufficient buildable area to accommodate
the proposed use. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code; Ord. 2004-19, 8-17-
2004)
11-2-5: BUILDABLE AREA:
All property, including subdivided lots, must have sufficient buildable area to
place a building or structure upon to meet the minimum standards of section
10-15-30 of this code (one-family and two-family dwellings). Building or
structure placement must comply with the setbacks of the zone where property is
located. The buildable area will be required to be placed on any proposed
subdivision plat or development plans for the purpose of notifying future
owners of the approved buildable area as per setbacks and easements. (Ord.
2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-2-6: SAVING EXISTING VEGETATION:
Developments shall be designed to incorporate existing large trees, clusters of
trees or clusters of larger shrubs. The planning commission, or a designated
subcommittee, shall review the appropriateness of removal of portions of these
types of vegetation if proposed in the development plan. The planning
commission may approve removal of some or all vegetation based on a
determination of the following criteria: benefits of the existing plant
material; the efforts made to save and incorporate the existing plant material
into the design of the project versus the problems the plant materials may
create for the project in terms of general construction techniques; impact the
removal will have on the character of the area; the topography of the site; or
harmful conditions the vegetation may create. Because one of the purposes of
development is to protect natural features, the planning commission may deny
approval of a development if it is determined there has been removal of trees
or shrubs prior to submittal. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-2-7: DEFINITIONS; WORDS, TERMS, PHRASES:
For the purpose of this title, the following shall apply:
ALLEY: A public or private vehicular street designed to serve as secondary
access to the side or rear of properties whose principal frontage is on some
other street.
AVERAGE SLOPE: A. The average slope of a parcel of land or any portion thereof
and shall be computed by applying the formula:
   S = 0.00229 x (i) x (L)
      A
to the natural slope of the land before any grading is commenced, as determined
from a topographic map having a scale of not less than one inch equals one
hundred feet (1" = 100'), and a contour interval of not more than five feet
(5'), where:
   0.00229   =   A conversion factor from square feet to acres
   S   =   Average slope (feet)
   i   =   Contour interval (feet), which is the vertical distance between
adjacent contour lines
   L   =   Summation of the length of contour lines within the subject parcel
(feet)
   A   =   Area of the subject parcel (acres), excluding areas of slope greater
than thirty percent (30%). The area considered shall not exceed five (5) acres.
   B.   Average slope shall be determined on an individual lot basis and on
areas of generally uniform slope. Average slope shall be determined with the
parcel in its natural condition, prior to any development. Cuts or fills shall
not be utilized to alter the slope determination.
BORROW: Earth material acquired for use in grading on a site.
BUILDABLE AREA: That portion of a lot or parcel which is eligible to place a
building or structure and complies with the setbacks of the zone where property
is located.
COLLECTIVE DRIVEWAY: A driveway, at least twelve feet (12') in width, serving
not more than two (2) lots, or two (2) residential dwelling units, or twenty
feet (20') in width serving not more than two (2) lots and four (4) single
residential dwelling units and not exceeding four hundred feet (400') in
length.
CONCEPT PLAN: The initial drawings and sketches done by the developer or
property owner that sets forth his basic ideas and concepts for the development
of a tract of property.
CUT: See definition of Excavation.
DEVELOPABLE LAND: Land under thirty percent (30%) slope which is capable of
being improved, subject to the sensitive lands ordinance (see chapter 8 of this
title) and other requirements within this title, with landscaping, buildings or
parking. Land devoted to wetlands preservation shall not be considered
developable land.
DEVELOPMENT: The total area of the parcel of land on which a building permit is
to be issued or the total area of property being improved.
DRIVEWAY: A paved area used for ingress or egress of vehicles, and allowing
access from a street to one building, structure or facility.
EASEMENT: The right to use a quantity of land set aside over which a liberty,
privilege or advantage in land, existing distinct from the ownership of the
land, is granted to the public or to some particular person or part of the
public.
EXCAVATION: The mechanical removal of earth material.
FILL: A deposit of earth material by artificial means.
FINAL APPROVAL: The signing of the final plat by: a) the City Council for major
final plats, including all plats having more than three (3) lots, road
dedications and/or City easements; or b) by the City Engineer for minor final
plats having three (3) or less lots.
FINAL PLAT: A map or chart of a land division with accompanying supplementary
documents, which has been accurately surveyed, and such survey marked on the
ground so that streets, alleys, blocks, lots and other divisions can be
identified.
FRENCH DRAINS: A sump or trench filled with crushed rock or gravel intended to
receive stormwater discharge.
FRONTAGE IMPROVEMENTS: The construction of curb, gutter, sidewalk, road section
and utilities along frontage of development.
GENERAL PLAN: A document that Pleasant Grove City adopts that sets forth
general guidelines for land use within the Municipality, as set forth Utah Code
Annotated sections 10-9-301 and 10-9-302. "General Plan" includes what is also
commonly referred to as a "Master Plan" or "Comprehensive Plan".
GRADING: Any excavating or filling, or combination thereof.
GRADING PLANS: A topographic development plan prepared by a licensed
professional engineer showing contours.
HILLSIDE AREA: Any lot or parcel with an average slope greater than fifteen
percent (15%).
INTERVENING PROPERTY: Property located between the existing service facility
and the corner lot.
IRRIGATION DITCH: Any system of canals or ditches originally constructed for
irrigation use and maintained primarily for that use.
LICENSED LAND SURVEYOR: A person licensed in the State of Utah who is qualified
to practice land surveying by reason of his special knowledge of the technique
of measuring land, the basic principles of mathematics, the related physical
and applied sciences, the relevant requirements of law for adequate evidence,
and the requisites to surveying of real property.
LICENSED PROFESSIONAL ENGINEER: A person licensed in the State of Utah who is
qualified to practice engineering by reason of his special knowledge of the
mathematical, physical and engineering sciences, and the principles and methods
of engineering analysis and design, acquired by engineering education and
experience.
METES AND BOUNDS: The description of a lot or parcel of land by courses and
distances.
NATURAL FEATURES: Includes drainage swales, wetlands, rock outcroppings,
streams and concentrated native strands of large shrubs or trees.
NATURAL STATE: A lot or parcel which has not been subjected to grading, removal
of vegetation or building development.
OFF SITE FACILITIES: Facilities outside of the boundaries of the subdivision
which are designed and located to serve the needs of the subdivision or
adjacent properties; usually lying between a development and existing
facilities.
ON SITE FACILITIES: Facilities installed within or on the perimeter of the
subdivision or development site.
OVER SIZE FACILITIES: Facilities with added capacity designed to serve other
property in addition to the land within the boundaries of the subdivision or
development site.
PARKING LOT: An open area, other than a street or alley, used for the parking
of more than four (4) automobiles, whether for free or for compensation.
PARKING LOT AISLE: The traveled way by which cars enter and depart parking
spaces. Aisle width standards are set forth in the diagrams at section
10-18-4 of this Code. Parking aisles shall not be considered streets for
purposes of this title.
PHASING: To complete a development with a minimum of multiple stages in a
logical order.
PRELIMINARY APPROVAL: A recommendation from the Planning Commission.
PRELIMINARY PLAT: A map or chart of a proposed land division with accompanying
required supplementary documents.
REMOVAL: Killing vegetation by any means, including, but not limited to,
spraying, complete extraction or cutting.
RESUBDIVISION: The changing of any existing lot or lots of any subdivision plat
previously recorded in the records of the County Recorder.
RIPRAP: A loose assemblage of broken stones erected on ground for use as a
foundation to prevent erosion.
ROUGH GRADE: The stage at which the grade is within eight inches (8") of the
grade shown on the approved final engineering drawings.
SECOND ACCESS: Providing a second point of access that is open to the public
for ingress and egress to a development under all weather conditions.
SENSITIVE LANDS: Any land area whose destruction or disturbance could
immediately affect the life of the community by either:
   A.   Creating hazards such as flooding and landslides; or
   B.   Destroying important public resources such as water supplies and the
water quality of lakes or rivers; or
   C.   Wasting important productive lands and renewable resources.
SHALLOW GROUND WATER AREA: That portion of the City where the depth to water is
less than ten feet (10') from the ground surface, and which would thus
adversely impede construction of subsurface structure. Such locations are
determined by geotechnical investigations.
SITE: Any lot or parcel of land.
STREET: Any street, avenue, boulevard, road, lane, roadway, viaduct, alley or
other way for the movement of vehicular traffic which is in an existing state,
county or municipal roadway; or a street or way shown upon a plat, heretofore
approved, pursuant to law, or approved by official action, and includes the
land between street lines, whether improved or unimproved, and may comprise
pavement, shoulders, gutter, sidewalks, parking area and other areas within the
right of way. For the purpose of this title, streets shall be classified as
defined in subsections A through H of this definition:
   A.   Major Highway: A major regional highway, including an expressway,
freeway or interstate highway designed to carry vehicular traffic:
      1.   Into, out of or through the regional area (inter-region); and
      2.   From the political subdivision of the region to another, or from an
inter-regional highway (inter-regional).
   B.   Major Or Arterial Street: A street or road designed to carry vehicular
traffic from one part of a political subdivision to another part of that same
subdivision, or to adjoining political subdivision. Vehicular volumes will be
designed for a minimum of eight thousand (8,000) average daily trips (ADT).
   C.   Collector Street: A street or road designed to carry vehicular traffic
from one or more individual residential or nonresidential units to or from a
major street to a major highway. Vehicular volumes will be designed for two
thousand (2,000) or greater ADT.
   D.   Local Or Minor Street: A street or road designed to carry vehicular
traffic from one or more individual residential or nonresidential units to or
from a collector street. Vehicular volumes will be designed for up to two
thousand (2,000) ADT.
   E.   Alley: A public or private vehicular street designed to serve as
secondary access to the side or rear of properties whose principal frontage is
on some other street.
   F.   Cul-De-Sac: A short dead end street terminating in a vehicular
turnaround area.
   G.   Service Frontage Road: A street or road paralleling and abutting major
streets to provide access to adjacent property so that each adjacent lot will
not have direct access to the major street.
   H.   Stub Street: A street or road extending from within a subdivision
boundary and terminating there in a temporary vehicular turnaround. Stub
streets are provided to permit adjacent connecting street parcels of land to be
developed later with an adjacent connecting street system (see section
10-15-42 of this code).
   I.   Lane: A narrow country road that existed in a rural area prior to
development.
STREET RIGHT OF WAY: That portion of land dedicated to public use for street
and utility purposes.
SUBDIVIDER: Any person or legal entity laying out or making a land division for
the purpose of sale, or selling for himself or others any subdivision or any
part thereof.
SUBDIVISION: A. Any land that is divided, resubdivided or proposed to be
divided into two (2) or more lots, parcels, sites, units, plots or other
division of land for the purpose, whether immediate or future, for offer, sale,
lease or development either on the installment plan or upon any and all other
plans, terms and conditions.
   B.   "Subdivision" includes:
      1.   The division or development of land whether by deed, metes and
bounds description, devise and testacy, lease, map, plat, or other recorded
instrument; and
      2.   Except as provided in subsection C of this definition, divisions of
land for all residential and nonresidential uses, including land used or to be
used for commercial, agricultural, and industrial purposes.
   C.   "Subdivision" does not include:
      1.   A bona fide division or partition of agricultural land for the
purpose of joining one of the resulting separate parcels to a contiguous parcel
of unsubdivided agricultural land, if neither the resulting combined parcel nor
the parcel remaining from the division or partition violates an applicable
zoning ordinance;
      2.   A recorded agreement between owners of adjoining properties
adjusting their mutual boundary if:
         a.   No new lot is created; and
         b.   The adjustment does not result in a violation of applicable
zoning ordinances; or
      3.   A recorded document, executed by the owner of record, revising the
legal description of more than one contiguous parcel of property into one legal
description encompassing all such parcels of property.
   D.   The joining of a subdivided parcel of property to another parcel of
property that has not been subdivided does not constitute a "subdivision" under
this definition as to the unsubdivided parcel of property or subject the
unsubdivided parcel to the Municipality's subdivision ordinance.
SUBSURFACE DRAINAGE: Any system of pipes, canals, ditches, etc., that
intercepts the ground water and carries it to Utah Lake.
SURFACE DRAINAGE: That amount of water runoff caused as a result of
precipitation or irrigation.
VICINITY PLAN: A map or chart showing the relationship of streets and lands
within a proposed subdivision to the existing or planned streets and lands in
the surrounding area. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code; Ord. 2004-19,
8-17-2004; Ord. 2017-25, 5-16-2017)
11-2-8: COMPLIANCE WITH GENERAL PLAN POLICIES:
All proposed developments will be reviewed for compliance with the adopted
General Plan and the policies found therein. This review is to ensure that the
land use policy will ensure controlled development in areas with limited local
services. The approval of developments will be based upon determining strict
compliance with the policies of the General Plan, high water table, sensitive
lands and other ordinances and regulations. The following measures will be used
when considering development for approval: (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003
Code)
   A.   Upgrade Of Affected Facilities: Any developer that places local
facilities at or near capacity will be required to upgrade the affected
facilities.
   B.   Environmental Constraints: The extent of the development shall be
related to the property's environmental constraints.
   C.   Special Studies: Developers may be required to conduct special studies
as needed to properly access the nature of environmental constraints, and to
devise accepted methodologies to mitigate any potential adverse impacts.
   D.   Density Computation: Densities for developments will be computed using
net rather than gross acreage. Lands not capable of being improved or used as
integrated open space will be excluded from density calculations.
   E.   Existing Infrastructure: Land should be developed where existing
infrastructure is in place.
   F.   Affordable Housing: Affordable housing, without sacrificing quality of
development or the neighborhood is encouraged. Developers are encouraged to
provide a larger range of housing choices.
   G.   Access: Where possible, direct access from residential property to
collector and arterial streets will not be permitted. Access to new residential
development shall be provided by local streets. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-2-9: SCHOOL SITES, OTHER PUBLIC PLACES:
In developing property, consideration shall be given to sites for schools,
parks and other areas for public use, as outlined in the General Plan. Any
provision for such open spaces shall be indicated on the preliminary plan in
order that it may be determined in what manner such areas will be dedicated to,
or acquired by, the appropriate agency. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-2-10: CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE OF PRIVATE ROADS AND DRIVEWAYS BY CITY
PROHIBITED:
   A.   Conditions: The City shall not open, grade, pave or perform any
maintenance work on any private or undedicated street, road or alley, and the
City will refrain from laying utility lines in any street which has not:
      1.   Been accepted by the City as a public street or alley; and
      2.   Which has not received the approval of the City Council or the City
Engineer as part of a final plat of a subdivision or development, unless an
easement is granted thereof.
   B.   Standards And Specifications: The City shall not accept or maintain
streets or other public ways unless said streets have been constructed in
accordance with standards and specifications which have been adopted by the
City Council. (Ord. 2017-25, 5-16-2017)
11-2-11: WORK TO BE DONE BY ENGINEER OR SURVEYOR:
All engineering work or surveying of property must be done by or under
direction of a licensed professional engineer or licensed land surveyor
registered in the State. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-2-12: DEDICATION OF WATER RIGHTS UPON DEVELOPMENT:
   A.   Dedication: Any person or legal entity ("applicant") who shall develop
shall dedicate sufficient water rights to the City to meet the future culinary
and/or secondary water needs of said development. The water to be dedicated to
the City shall be Pleasant Grove Irrigation Company water stock.
      1.   Residential use (single-family):
         a.   Water shall be dedicated in the amount equal to one and eight-
tenths (1.8) shares per acre of land contained in the development, excluding
streets.
         b.   Water required shall be dedicated prior to the recordation of the
development plat when a new subdivision is created or at the time of building
permit issuance when building on an empty parcel.
         c.   A credit for the land area of any lots with existing residences,
with a historic metered water use, is given at the time of water requirement
calculation. Existing residences served by the City do not require additional
water dedication due to inclusion in a development.
      2.   Residential use (multi-family) and commercial use:
         a.   Water Shall Be Dedicated As Follows:
            (1)   Exterior landscaped area: Dedicate water in the amount equal
to one and eight-tenths (1.8) shares per acre of landscaped area contained in
the development.
            (2)   Exterior water features: This includes swimming pools,
jacuzzis, ponds, fountains, or similar water using amenities. Dedicate water in
the amount equal to the average annual water use for the proposed facility as
determined by the City Engineer.
            (3)   Utility and/or joint use area interior water uses: This
includes the internal water used in clubhouses, service buildings, or similar
structures for use in showers, saunas, jacuzzis, sinks, toilets, etc. Dedicate
water in the amount determined by the City Engineer.
            (4)   Private interior water uses: This includes the water used in
all interior unit spaces. Dedicate water in the amount determined by the city
engineer.
         b.   Water Required Shall Be Dedicated:
            (1)   Multi-family residential: Water required shall be dedicated
prior to the recordation of the development plat or at the time of building
permit issuance when building on an empty parcel.
            (2)   Commercial use:
               (A)   For exterior water uses and landscaping: Water required
shall be dedicated prior to beginning work on the approved site plan and to
issuance of the building permit for the building shell.
               (B)   For interior water uses: Water required shall be dedicated
prior to the issuance of the building permit for the tenant improvements (TI).
Water requirements are based on the first tenant use and are not increased or
decreased with subsequent remodeling of interior space via another TI building
permit.
         c.   Water Use By Existing Facilities: A credit for the water use by
existing facilities with a historic metered water use is given at the time of
water requirement calculation. Additional water is not required for remodeling
of existing facilities where square footage or number of overall units is not
changing.
      3.   Upon dedication of the water stock, the applicant shall have no
further interest of any kind or nature in said water stock.
      4.   Water dedicated will be held in trust by the city for future
culinary and/or secondary use. The city may use the water for culinary and/or
secondary purposes in any area of the city in which it deems appropriate, so
long as culinary and/or secondary water from other sources is made available to
the developed land.
   B.   Relief Petition: Any applicant for development within Pleasant Grove
City, may file a relief petition with the city recorder seeking relief from all
or part of the water right dedication requirements as contained in this section
on the basis that the requirement, as applied to the applicant or to the
specific property for which the subdivision or building permit is being
requested are inequitable, or should be modified for any just cause. The
applicant may petition the city for relief from the requirements pursuant to
the following provisions:
      1.   Relief From "Type" Of Water Required: The applicant must demonstrate
the inability to obtain the required water shares requested to the satisfaction
of the city. If a relief petition is granted, the applicant shall be allowed to
meet the water right dedication requirements in one of the following methods as
recommended by city staff in the formal decision:
         a.   The applicant may transfer other surface irrigation shares or
water rights that can be readily used in the city's secondary water system. All
proposed water rights transfers shall be reviewed by the city engineer and may
or may not be acceptable to the city for water rights dedication. When
permitted, the amount of stock in other irrigation companies must be equivalent
to shares of Pleasant Grove Irrigation Company stock. Only shares in approved
irrigation companies will be accepted.
         b.   The applicant may be allowed to pay the city in cash the
equivalent cost of the required water rights. This money will be used by the
city to recoup the cost of previously purchased water rights or purchase new
water rights. The cost assessed is determined by the city engineer based on
recent market prices for local surface irrigation and water rights.
         c.   The applicant may transfer local water rights to the city that
have been historically used on the specific ground that is being developed. All
water rights transfers including change applications, assignment, use
retirement, etc., are the responsibility of the applicant. All proposed water
rights transfers shall be reviewed by the city engineer and may or may not be
acceptable to the city for water rights dedication. For residential
developments, the transfer must be completed prior to the recording of the
final plat. For other than residential developments, the transfer must be
completed prior to the issuance of a building permit.
         d.   The applicant may be allowed to transfer another type of water if
it is determined by the city engineer to be in the best interest of the city.
      2.   Relief From "Amount" Of Water Required: The applicant must
demonstrate the inequity of the requirement to the satisfaction of the city. If
a relief petition is granted, the applicant shall be given a revised water
right dedication requirement as recommended by city staff in the formal
decision.
      3.   Relief From Any Other Water Requirement: The relief petition process
may not be used for reasons other than the type or amount of water required.
   C.   Relief Petition Process:
      1.   Time For Filing Notice Of Petition And Petition: No later than ten
(10) calendar days from formal action by the city on any subdivision or
building permit application wherein a requirement for water rights dedication
is specified, the applicant shall file a notice of petition in writing with the
city recorder. Within thirty (30) days of filing a notice of petition, the
applicant shall file a relief petition with the city recorder.
      2.   Information To Be Submitted With Relief Petition: The relief
petition must be submitted on a form acceptable to the city and must be
accompanied at a minimum by the following information:
         a.   Name of the applicant;
         b.   Name and business address of the current owner of the property,
form of ownership, whether sole proprietorship, for profit or not for profit
corporation, partnership, joint venture, limited liability company, or other,
and if owned by a corporation, partnership, joint venture, or limited liability
company, the name and address of all principal shareholders, members, or
partners;
         c.   Nature of the interest owned by the applicant in the subject
property;
         d.   A complete description of all water rights and water shares owned
by the applicant;
         e.   A complete description of all water rights and water shares which
have been utilized on the subject property during the five (5) years prior to
the date of the application;
         f.   A description of all water rights and water shares transferred to
the city by the applicant, related to the subject property;
         g.   A description of all water rights and water shares transferred to
the city by any prior owner of the property during the five (5) years prior to
the date of the application, related to the subject property;
         h.   A complete description of the disposition or sale of all water
rights and water shares related to the subject property during the five (5)
year period prior to the date of the application;
         i.   All studies and reports commissioned by the applicant, agents of
the applicant, or prior owners of the subject property within the previous five
(5) years concerning water usage, and/or availability, related to the subject
property;
         j.   Information from a title report showing all recorded liens,
encumbrances, and ownership interests related to all water rights and water
shares related to the subject property as of the date of the petition;
         k.   Copies of all documents evidencing the existence of decreed water
rights and water shares related to the subject property;
         l.   The complete detailed factual basis for the applicant's assertion
that the connection requirements for the city's culinary or pressurized
irrigation systems are inequitable or should be modified as to the applicant,
related to the subject property for which connection is sought;
         m.   A specific description of the modification from the water right
dedication requirements which the applicant asserts are necessary, to the
minimum extent necessary to prevent the requirements from being inequitable,
together with the factual basis for said assertion;
         n.   The petition shall be signed by the applicant and verified.
      3.   Additional Information: City staff may request additional
information reasonably necessary, in their opinion, to arrive at a conclusion
concerning the relief petition.
      4.   Failure To Submit Information: In the event that any of the
information required to be submitted by the applicant is not reasonably
available, the applicant shall file with the petition a statement of the
information that cannot be obtained and shall describe the reasons why such
information is unavailable.
      5.   Decision By City Staff: No later than fifteen (15) days after the
filing of a complete relief petition, together with all required and requested
supporting information and documentation required by the city, city staff shall
issue a decision, unless a reasonable extension of time is agreed to by both
staff and the applicant.
      6.   Burden Of Proof: The applicant shall have the burden of proving that
the strict application of the city water right dedication requirements are
inequitable or should be modified, in whole or in part, as applied to the
specific applicant or property for which approval is sought.
      7.   Findings Of Staff: City staff shall, on the basis of the evidence
presented, make specific findings as part of its decision which may include the
following:
         a.   Whether the applicant has submitted adequate supporting
information with a relief petition;
         b.   A determination as to all water rights and water shares which
have been previously transferred to the city with regard to the subject
property;
         c.   Whether, in the opinion of the staff, the imposition of the water
rights dedication requirements, are inequitable or should be modified, as
applied to the applicant or to the subject property.
      8.   Report And Decision Of Staff:
         a.   City staff, based upon the evidence and findings, shall make a
report and decision concerning the relief petition.
         b.   If staff grants approval of the relief petition, in whole or in
part, then the report of staff shall discuss the type and extent of
modifications necessary, in the opinion of staff, to prevent the water right
dedication requirements from having an inequitable effect.
         c.   The report and decision of staff shall be mailed to the applicant
no later than ten (10) days after the decision.
      9.   City Council Appeal: In the event the applicant feels the decision
of city staff is not equitable, the applicant can file an appeal to the city
council. The appeal shall be filed with the city recorder within fifteen (15)
days of the decision of staff. The city council shall hold a hearing to review
the appeal within thirty (30) days of receipt of the appeal. At the hearing,
the applicant may testify, and examine witnesses, and present facts and
evidence. All witnesses shall be sworn and testify under oath. At the hearing
the city council may limit the testimony and evidence to new testimony and
evidence. The city council shall approve, in whole or in part, or disapprove
the relief petition. The city council may modify or waive the water right
dedication requirements to the extent reasonably necessary to prevent the water
right dedication requirements from being inequitable as to the applicant or as
to the subject property and may condition such modification or waiver upon
approval of specific development plans.
      10.   Findings Of The City Council: The city council shall, on the basis
of the report and decision of staff and the evidence and testimony presented,
make specific findings as part of its decision. The findings may adopt, change,
or modify the findings of the staff.
      11.   Decision Of The City Council: The decision of the city council
shall be mailed to the applicant no later than thirty (30) days after the
hearing.
      12.   Decision Final: The decision of the city council shall be final.
(Ord. 2012-6, 2-21-2012)
11-2-13: AMENDMENTS MAY BE REQUIRED:
   A.   Findings: Before approving a preliminary plan or a final plat of a
subdivision, the planning commission may require amendments or modifications to
the plan if it finds that:
      1.   The layout of the development or subdivision does not conform to
acceptable standards of design as set forth in this title.
      2.   The development or subdivision is not provided with adequate ingress
or egress.
      3.   The development or subdivision contains geologic, soil, water or
other hazards which would be detrimental to the subdivision, surrounding area
or to the city.
      4.   The development or subdivision does not provide the required
improvements or quality of improvements, or does not comply with other
requirements as set forth in this title.
      5.   The dimensions of the development or subdivision, or any lot, do not
mathematically close.
   B.   Scope Of Amendments Or Modifications: Such amendments or modifications
shall be sufficient in all cases to correct the inadequacies so that the
development or subdivision will conform to the requirements of this title.
(Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-2-14: COMPLIANCE WITH FINAL PLAT:
Every approved development or subdivision shall be constructed, developed, or
otherwise completed according to the provisions of this title, in conformance
to the approved final development plans or plat and supplementary documents. It
is the responsibility of the developer or subdivider to ensure that such
provisions are correctly constructed, installed or otherwise completed. Failure
to comply with this provision shall constitute grounds for immediate
termination of all work activity associated with such development or
subdivision. Before the resumption of work activity, the developer or
subdivider shall accomplish one of the following:
   A.   Agree, in writing, to reconstruct, at his cost, those items not in
conformance with the provisions of this title before the release of the
security guaranteeing improvements.
   B.   Obtain a variance to the provisions of this title in accordance with
chapter 5 of this title. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-2-15: CLEAR TITLE TO PROPERTY REQUIRED:
In the event that the title insurance or preliminary title report discloses any
boundary exception or serious defect of title which would affect the follow
through of the developer or subdivider, or implementation of this chapter in
any way, the project shall be halted until the exception or defect has been
cured by the owner. By subsequent filing, the owner may submit documents to
satisfy the city that it has remedied the exception or the defect, which remedy
shall be approved by the city attorney before construction may commence on the
project. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
CHAPTER 3
STREET STANDARDS AND IMPROVEMENTS REQUIRED
SECTION:
11-3-1: Purpose Of Chapter
11-3-2: Bonding For Improvements Required As A Condition For Plat Recordation
11-3-3: Exceptions
11-3-4: Street Standards
11-3-5: Block Standards
11-3-6: Lot Standards
11-3-7: Cuts In Pavement
11-3-8: Parkways
11-3-1: PURPOSE OF CHAPTER:
It is the intent and purpose of this chapter to require the same standard of
streets adjacent to single lots and those outside of subdivisions as are
required for lots and parcels developed within subdivisions, including, but not
limited to, water and sewer mains, curb, gutter, sidewalk, and street hard
surfacing. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-3-2: BONDING FOR IMPROVEMENTS REQUIRED AS A CONDITION FOR PLAT RECORDATION:
It is hereby declared unlawful for the developer of any parcel of ground within
the City for residential, industrial or commercial purposes to build on the
parcel without constructing the adjacent streets that provide public access to
the developed property. Bonding for the development of the streets and
installation of culinary and secondary water and sewer mains, curb, gutter,
sidewalk, and street paving for the full lot frontage throughout the entire
development, shall be considered a necessary condition precedent to recordation
of the final plat. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-3-3: EXCEPTIONS:
To the extent that real property is developed in areas where other streets are
not fully improved (e.g., the building of a farmhouse in an agricultural area
where there are no other properties developed with curb, gutter and sidewalk),
a building permit may be issued upon receipt from the developer of the property
of a guarantee bond to install the improvements at a later date consistent with
street development of adjacent properties. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-3-4: STREET STANDARDS:
The type and arrangement of roadways peripheral to and abutting any development
shall be in compliance with the City major street plan. Projects that are
located on or next to a collector or arterial street shall be designed and
developed so the public street continues through the project in a logical, safe
manner. Projects that are located at the end of stubbed local public streets
may be required to extend the street through the development based on the
proposed circulation needs of the area, as determined by the Planning
Commission. During the preliminary approval, the Planning Commission, upon
recommendation of the planning and engineering staff, shall determine if the
street should be extended as a through street or as a cul-de-sac.
   A.   Street Widths: Street widths shall conform with the City major street
plan as adopted.
      1.   Minor street dedications shall have a minimum width of fifty six
feet (56') with a pavement width of forty feet (40').
      2.   All City streets designated in the general plan as "boulevard"
streets require a five foot (5') planting strip (to accommodate trees and grass
between the curb and sidewalk).
   B.   Cul-De-Sacs: Each cul-de-sac shall have a minimum dedicated diameter of
one hundred twelve feet (112').
      1.   The maximum length of a cul-de-sac shall not exceed four hundred
feet (400'), except that a maximum of six hundred fifty feet (650') may be
approved through conditional use permit by the Planning Commission, with
positive recommendation by the City Fire Marshal. In such case, conditions
regarding the looping or installation of additional water lines may be
required. Turnaround areas shall be one hundred feet (100') in diameter.
      2.   Cul-de-sacs shall be used only where unusual drainage or land
ownership configurations exist which make other designs undesirable or
impossible; and where street plans for the area do not require through
circulation.
   C.   Alleys: Where accepted by the Planning Commission, alleys shall be a
minimum of twenty feet (20') in width and shall be fully paved.
   D.   Easements: Where alleys are not provided, easements of not less than
ten feet (10') on all sides of lots shall be provided.
   E.   Street Intersections: Streets will intersect each other as nearly as
possible at right angles. All streets shall intersect at an angle of not less
than eighty degrees (80°). Offsets in street alignment between ten feet (10')
and one hundred fifty feet (150') shall be prohibited.
   F.   Street Grades: Minimum street grades shall be four-tenths of one
percent (0.4%) and maximum street grades shall be ten percent (10%), except
that the Planning Commission shall have the power to require a steeper or
lesser grade when, in the opinion of the City Engineer, the best development of
the land is thereby secured.
   G.   Street Curves: Where the street lines within a block deflect from each
other at any point more than three degrees (3°), there shall be a connecting
curve. The radius of the curve for the inner street line shall be not less than
three hundred fifty feet (350') for all arterial streets, two hundred fifty
feet (250') for collector streets, and one hundred feet (100') for minor
streets. Local streets shall be designed with curves where possible.
   H.   Corner Returns: Curbs at all intersections shall be rounded with curves
having a minimum radius as indicated in the standard specifications and
drawings. Property lines at street intersections shall be rounded with a curve.
In the event that a traffic signal is planned, the property line shall be
created by drawing a line between the PC and PT of the corner return.
   I.   Design Specifications: Specifications for the design of street subbase,
base, hard surfacing, curb and gutters, sidewalks, and the treatment of
drainage courses shall comply with standard specifications as adopted by the
City and administered by the City Engineer.
   J.   Street Names: New streets names shall not duplicate those already
existing. A street, obviously a continuation of another already in existence,
shall bear the same name. The numerical system of street designations shall be
maintained and extended where possible.
   K.   Street Dedications And Paving: All streets shall be dedicated for
public use. The full width (described above) of all streets within a
subdivision shall be dedicated and the roadway paved. No partial streets will
be permitted except:
      1.   When a new street is on the border of a subdivision, the side of the
street on the outside of the subdivision does not require dedication or
improvements behind the curb and gutter provided the edge of the right-of-way
dedicated is the subdivision boundary and no nuisance strip is created between
the dedication and other private property.
      2.   In cases where the right-of-way needed for the full pavement width
(back of curb to back of curb) of a street cannot be obtained after a
reasonable, good faith effort on the part of an applicant, where the use of
eminent domain by the City is the only remaining option, the City Council may
approve a narrower roadway pavement. The applicant:
         a.   Shall provide evidence of the effort to obtain the right-of- way.
         b.   Shall provide the maximum width possible, however in no case
shall the narrower roadway provide a pavement of less than thirty feet (30')
for residential streets and thirty five feet (35') for collectors or greater.
         c.   Shall meet any additional requirements of the City Engineer and
Public Works Director with regard to the pavement, parking, or other issues on
any partial street.
         d.   May not propose any lots which obtain required frontage on any
partial street.
         e.   May not use a partial street as a required access to the required
frontage of any lot.
City staff will present the request for the partial street as part of the plat
review/approval process before the Planning Commission and City Council. Public
comment will be taken on the request at the public hearing for the plat. The
Planning Commission will make a recommendation to the City Council on the
request.
      3.   When right-of-way needed to connect a proposed subdivision to an
existing street cannot be obtained after a reasonable, good faith effort on the
part of an applicant, where the use of eminent domain by the City is the only
remaining option, the City Council may approve a temporary access to the
subdivision. The following shall apply:
         a.   The temporary access shall be abandoned as a public access when a
public street access meeting City standards becomes available to connect the
subdivision to existing streets.
         b.   The applicant shall provide evidence of the effort to obtain the
standard access right-of-way.
         c.   The subdivision property shall be included in the officially
adopted local streets vicinity plan.
         d.   No lot may obtain frontage on any temporary access.
         e.   The subdivision shall include an area of right-of-way dedication
to meet street standards at the time of development approval.
         f.   Excluding street width and standard street improvements (i.e.,
curb and gutter, park strip, and sidewalk), the temporary access shall be paved
to meet City standards for a public street.
         g.   All temporary accesses shall comply with the following standards:
            (1)   Minimum width: Twenty five feet (25').
            (2)   Minimum length: The minimum lot width for the zone.
            (3)   Maximum length: Three hundred feet (300').
            (4)   Minimum curve radius: One hundred feet (100').
            (5)   Maximum lots served by a temporary access: Three (3) unless
approved by Council with positive recommendations from engineer and Fire
Marshal after review of safety and traffic issues.
            (6)   Minimum frontage on a public street: Twenty five feet (25').
            (7)   Minimum pavement width: Twenty feet (20').
            (8)   Surfacing standard: With the exception of an optional
concrete driveway entrance where the access connects to the isolated standard
street within the development, the entire access shall be surfaced with either
asphalt or concrete adequate to support the weight of a fire apparatus (H-20
standard).
   L.   Relations To Adjoining Streets: The arrangement of streets in new
developments shall make provision for the continuation of the existing streets
in the adjoining area (or their proper protection where adjoining land is not
subdivided) at the same or greater width (but in no case less than the required
minimum width) unless variations are deemed necessary by the Planning
Commission. Where the Planning Commission determines that it is desirable to
provide for street access to adjoining property in order to provide orderly
development of a street system, proposed streets shall be extended by
dedication to the boundary of such property.
   M.   Sidewalks: Sidewalks shall be five feet (5') in width except where
other widths are deemed appropriate by the City Engineer, and comply with the
latest Americans With Disabilities Act requirements.
   N.   Improvements: All improvements within a public right-of-way must
conform to the standard drawings and specifications set by the City Engineer.
   O.   Stub Streets: If a stub street exceeds one hundred feet (100') in
length, it must be terminated in a temporary turnaround having a minimum
diameter of ninety six feet (96') or an approved hammerhead or tee
configuration as approved by the City Engineer. The turnaround area must have a
paved surface with either asphalt or concrete adequate to support the weight of
a fire apparatus (H-20 standard) (see section
10-15-42 of this Code).
   P.   Seal Coat: A crack seal and seal coat is required to be applied on all
new asphalt pavement and patches approximately one year after the end of the
final inspection of the project. The City has implemented a fee to provide for
this requirement. Payment of the fee is required prior to holding a
preconstruction meeting or within two (2) weeks of receiving notice of the
payment amount from the City Engineer. Details regarding the fee and the policy
governing this requirement can be found in the Standard Specifications adopted
by the City. (Ord. 2018-15, 6-12-2018)
11-3-5: BLOCK STANDARDS:
   A.   Length: The maximum length of blocks shall be one thousand three
hundred feet (1,300') and the minimum length of blocks shall be four hundred
feet (400'). In blocks over eight hundred feet (800') in length, the subdivider
shall dedicate a passageway or alley through the block at approximately the
center of the block. Such passageway or alley shall not be less than ten feet
(10') in width.
   B.   Width: The width of blocks shall be sufficient to allow two (2) tiers
of lots.
   C.   Second Access: A second access shall be required if a street with a
single means of ingress and egress, and having a turnaround, exceeds a maximum
average daily trip (ADT) level of two hundred fifty (250). ADT studies shall be
approved by the City Engineer.
   D.   Traffic Study: A traffic study shall be required when determined by the
Plan Coordinating Committee. Those items to be considered in the study shall
include: pedestrians, bicycles, motor vehicles, street design and other items
as determined by the committee. The traffic study shall be completed by the
applicant and submitted at the time of application. Modifications to the
traffic study will be required if the proposed project changes during the
review process or all the required information is not included in the first
submittal. A traffic study shall be signed and stamped by a licensed
professional engineer and approved by the City Engineer. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-
2000)
11-3-6: LOT STANDARDS:
   A.   Building Sites: The lot arrangement, design and shape shall be such
that lots will provide a compact body of land for buildings and be properly
related to topography and conform to requirements set forth herein. Lots shall
not contain peculiarly shaped elongations solely to provide necessary square
footage which would be unusable for normal purposes. The building pad must meet
zoning setback requirements for each lot and the buildable area must be shown
with appropriate setbacks for the zone in which it is located.
   B.   Lot Sizes: All lots shown on the subdivision plat must conform to the
minimum requirements of the zoning ordinance for the zone in which the
subdivision is located.
   C.   Lots Must Abut On Public Streets: Each lot shall abut on a street
dedicated by the subdivision plat or an existing publicly dedicated street,
except when approved by the Planning Commission. Interior lots having frontage
on two (2) streets shall be prohibited, except where topographic conditions
make such design desirable, and approval by the Planning Commission is gained.
(Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. Ord. 2000-48, 11-21-2000)
   D.   Corner Lots: Corner lots shall have dimensions sufficient for the
maintenance of required building setback lines on both streets, along with
sufficient area to comply with area requirements of the zoning ordinance.
Corner lot widths shall be measured in accordance with the definition of "lot,
corner" at section
10-6-2 of this Code, regardless of how a structure is situated on the lot.
(Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. Ord. 2000-48, 11-21-2000; 2003 Code)
   E.   Parts Of Lots: All remnants of lots below minimum size, left over after
subdividing a larger tract, must be attached to adjacent lots, and evidence of
such attachment submitted prior to the approval of the final plat. All lots
designated within a subdivision must meet the minimum standards of the zone
within which they are located.
   F.   Divided Lots: Where the lots covered by a subdivision include two (2)
or more parcels in separate ownership, all parcels shall be transferred by deed
to single ownership before approval of the final plat, and such transfer
recorded in the county recorder's office. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. Ord.
2000-48, 11-21-2000)
11-3-7: CUTS IN PAVEMENT:
No cuts shall be made in street pavement for at least five (5) years after hard
surfacing has been installed unless approved by the city council. (Ord. 2000-
23, 7-18-2000)
11-3-8: PARKWAYS:
The intent of this section is to maintain the appearance of parkways, protect
the users of parkways and improve environmental conditions. A parkway is the
strip of real property next to a road which is between the curb and sidewalk
(a.k.a. park strip or planter strip).
   A.   Where Required:
      1.   Parkways are required on all collector and larger class streets, as
designated in the general plan.
      2.   Residential streets in certain areas of the city designated for a
"rural" appearance also require parkways.
   B.   Construction Details:
      1.   All parkways shall be at least four feet (4') wide and meet all
requirements shown in the typical roadway section details of the city standard
drawings.
   C.   Landscaping Requirements:
      1.   General:
         a.   New development shall install landscaping consistent with this
section:
            (1)   At the time of construction for all development other than
single-family residential. Complete prior to issuance of occupancy permit
(certificate).
            (2)   Within the two (2) growing seasons following the date of
issuance of the occupancy permit (certificate) for single-family residential.
         b.   Existing development may alter or replace landscaping in a
parkway consistent with this section. The work shall be completed in a timely
manner with a maximum time of three (3) months to complete changes. Pruning or
removal of trees must be approved by the city.
         c.   Parkways over twenty four inches (24") in width shall be
landscaped in conformance with the provisions of this section.
         d.   Parkways less than or equal to twenty four inches (24") wide may
be finished with impervious materials, including brick pavers, concrete pavers
or concrete due to the maintenance and irrigation difficulties associated with
narrow vegetated parkways.
      2.   Parkway Trees:
         a.   Quantity: Parkway trees shall be provided in all parkways that
are at least four feet (4') in width, and shall be spaced not more than thirty
feet (30') apart (depending on the variety of tree).
         b.   Spacing: Parkway trees may be clustered or spaced linearly in the
right of way.
         c.   Size: Parkway trees shall have a minimum trunk size of one and
one-half inch (11/2") caliper.
         d.   Species: A variety of compatible species shall be included in the
planting plan. Species must be selected from the "boulevard- parkway trees"
section of the city's tree guide. Alternatives must be approved by the parks
director.
      3.   Parkway Ground Surface Treatment:
         a.   Landscape Materials: All parkways over two feet (2') in width
shall be landscaped entirely or with combinations of:
            (1)   Turf grass,
            (2)   Ground cover plants and shrubs,
            (3)   Decorative cobble rock, when part of a low water use
(xeriscape) design. A weed barrier is required. Cobble shall be at least three
inch (3") diameter and "washed". Small boulders, placed to be no higher than
eighteen inches (18") above the sidewalk, may be used as accents. Decorative
cobble rock may not cover more than sixty five percent (65%) of the landscaped
area. The remaining thirty five percent (35%) shall be appropriate ground cover
plants and shrubs.
         b.   Prohibited Materials: Materials prohibited in parkways include
rocks (other than as noted above), gravel, bark, asphalt, thorn bearing plant
species, and plants or other features over eighteen inches (18") in height at
maturity. These materials are prohibited for the reasons stated below:
            (1)   Rocks, gravel and bark are hazardous to pedestrians and
bicyclists, are difficult to walk across, particularly when covered with snow,
and are kicked out of the parkway causing potential traffic hazards, clog storm
drainage systems, and require additional city street cleaning and maintenance
costs.
            (2)   Asphalt rapidly deteriorates and is difficult to maintain.
            (3)   Thorn bearing plant species are hazardous to pedestrians and
bicyclists.
            (4)   Plantings and other features which exceed eighteen inches
(18") in height at maturity: are hazardous to pedestrians due to sight distance
problems, are difficult to walk across, provide a visual barrier to promote
crime, and limit access to vehicles parked adjacent to the parkway. Trees are
excepted.
      4.   Irrigation Sleeves: All development requiring street improvements
(curb, gutter, sidewalk and street trees) where parkways are required shall
install sufficient sleeves underneath the sidewalk to accommodate eventual
sprinkling systems to the parkway strip.
   D.   Maintenance:
      1.   General: In all areas of the city where parkways have been
installed, it shall be the responsibility of the abutting property owner to
maintain the parkway landscaping in a healthy, safe, attractive, and nuisance
free condition. This shall include taking appropriate measures to water and
trim the parkway, and to keep it weed free.
      2.   Trees: It shall be the responsibility of the city parks department
to periodically prune and/or spray the trees as needed. If a tree needs to be
