CHAPTER 9
CONDOMINIUMS
SECTION:
11-9-1: Definitions
11-9-2: Approval Required
11-9-3: Submission Of Application
11-9-4: Review By Community Development Department
11-9-5: Approval By Planning Commission
11-9-6: Approval By Mayor
11-9-7: Improvements Performance Bonds
11-9-8: Amended Submissions
11-9-9: Appeal Of Planning Commission's Or Mayor's Action
11-9-10: Submission Required; Condominium Conversion
11-9-11: Information Required
11-9-12: Report Of Building Official
11-9-13: Minimum Standards Required
11-9-14: Parking Requirements
11-9-15: Utility Requirements
11-9-16: Mechanical And Heating Requirements
11-9-17: Conversion Notice Required
11-9-18: Content Of Notice Of Conversion
11-9-19: Submission Of Notice Verification
11-9-20: Unlawful To Sell Or Lease
11-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
CONDOMINIUM OR CONDOMINIUM PROJECT: A plan or project whereby two (2) or more
units, whether contained in existing or proposed apartment, commercial or
industrial buildings or structures, or otherwise, are separately offered or
proposed to be offered for sale. "Condominium project" shall also mean the
property when the context so requires.
CONDOMINIUM OWNERSHIP ACT OR ACT: The provisions of Utah Code Annotated title
57, chapter 8.
CONDOMINIUM UNIT: A unit, together with the undivided interest in the common
areas and facilities appertaining to that unit. Any reference to a condominium
unit includes both the physical unit together with its appurtenant individual
interest, unless the reference is specifically limited to a time period unit.
CONVERSION: A proposed change in the type of ownership of a parcel or parcels
of land or existing structures from single ownership, such as an apartment
house or multi-family dwelling into a "condominium project", as herein defined,
with arrangements involving separate ownership of individual condominium units
and joint collective ownership of common areas or facilities.
DECLARATION: A recorded declaration containing covenants, conditions and
restrictions relating to the condominium project which shall be prepared in
conformance with the provisions of Utah Code Annotated section 57-8-10.
MAYOR: The duly elected or appointed, qualified and acting mayor of Pleasant
Grove City.
RECORD OF SURVEY MAP: A plat or plats of survey of land and units prepared in
accordance with the requirements in Utah Code Annotated section 57-8-13. When
"planning commission" is used in this chapter, this shall be construed to mean
planning commission staff.
UNIT: A separate physical part of a condominium project or property intended
for any type of independent use, including one or more rooms or spaces located
On one or more floors (or part or parts of floors) in a building, or a time
period unit as the context may require. A convertible space shall be treated as
a unit. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code)
11-9-2: APPROVAL REQUIRED:
Prior to the construction or conversion of any building to be used as a
condominium, the record of survey map, the bylaws and the declaration therefor,
shall be submitted to and be approved by the city in conformance with the
procedures, requirements and standards contained herein, as required under the
Utah condominium ownership act (Utah Code Annotated section 57-8-35). (Ord.
2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-9-3: SUBMISSION OF APPLICATION:
   A.   Information Required: The owner or developer of a proposed condominium
project desiring approval shall file an application with the planning
commission on a form prescribed by the city. Said application shall be
accompanied by:
      1.   Two (2) copies of a record of survey map, accurately drawn to scale
in conformance with the provisions of Utah Code Annotated section 57-8-13,
which shall be prepared by a licensed professional engineer or licensed land
surveyor registered in the state. The scale of said record of survey map shall
be no smaller than one inch equals forty feet (1" = 40').
      2.   Ten (10) copies of a project plan prepared to the same scale as the
record of survey map designating the location of buildings; present and needed
utilities and irrigation ditches; the intended use of common areas; the
location of utility lines and easements; and the location and extent of
storage, recreational facilities, parking, driveways, pedestrianways, curbs,
walls, fences, landscaping and sprinkling systems.
      3.   Two (2) copies of the proposed condominium declaration and bylaws.
      4.   Where conversion of an existing building is proposed as part of the
condominium project, a property report containing the information specified in
section
11-9-11 of this chapter, shall be submitted as part of the application,
together with a plan for all proposed improvements and repairs.
      5.   Proof of notice to tenants required by section
11-9-17 of this chapter, to be submitted prior to final condominium approval.
   B.   Filing Fees: To assist the city in defraying the cost involved in
publication and review of a condominium project, fees shall be submitted with
an application in the amounts as established by section
10-4-1 of this code.
   C.   Incomplete Applications: Incomplete applications may be accepted by the
city and reviewed for advisory comments by the planning commission, but shall
not be deemed filed, accepted or reviewed until complete. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-
2000)
11-9-4: REVIEW BY COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Required: Upon receipt of an application for approval of a condominium
project, the community development director shall review the application and
related documents to determine whether the project conforms to applicable
requirements of the Utah condominium ownership act, applicable building and
zoning ordinances of the district in which the condominium project is located,
standards applied to the condominium by provisions of this title, and any
requirements or provisions set forth in the report of property condition
submitted by the owner/developer and the building inspection division.
   B.   Finding Of Violations: If the community development director finds that
there are violations of applicable zoning, building or similar codes or
requirements, it may hold the application for the condominium project until
such violations have been corrected; or may recommend condominium approval
subject to the condition that the violations be corrected or bonded prior to
certification and recording. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-9-5: APPROVAL BY PLANNING COMMISSION:
   A.   Approval Conditions: Upon submission of the reports and recommendations
of the planning commission, the matter shall be presented for consideration to
the planning commission for condominium approval at a date not to exceed thirty
(30) days from the date of application. If the commission finds that the
project as proposed is in compliance, or that plans have been submitted which
will bring the structures into compliance with applicable codes and policies,
and that there will be no substantial hazard or detriment to the health, safety
or welfare of the community, the neighborhood, or prospective owners of the
condominium units, then the planning commission shall recommend to the mayor
condominium approval with any conditions which it deems appropriate. Such
conditions may include correction of violations of Building, Zoning, Health,
Fire or other codes, appropriate amendments to declarations, bylaws or
amendments to the record of survey map and the project plan which may enhance
or protect the environment of the condominium development and the neighborhood
in which it is located.
   B.   Denial: If the Planning Commission finds circumstances or conditions
which would constitute a hazard to the health, safety or welfare of the
community, the neighborhood, or prospective owners of the condominium project,
the commission may recommend denial of the project to the Mayor. (Ord. 2000-23,
7-18-2000)
11-9-6: APPROVAL BY MAYOR:
   A.   Consideration; Time Limit: Upon receipt of recommendation from the
Planning Commission, the Mayor shall, within thirty (30) days, consider
approval of the condominium project.
   B.   Approval Conditions: If the Mayor finds that the project is in
compliance with, or has presented plans which will bring the structure under
compliance with applicable zoning, building and other appropriate ordinances
and policies, and that the project will not create substantial detriment to
residents of the City, the neighborhood, or prospective condominium owners, the
Mayor shall grant condominium approval with any conditions deemed appropriate
to ensure an attractive and safe environment.
   C.   Denial: If the Mayor finds circumstances or conditions which would
constitute a hazard to the health, safety or welfare of the community, the
neighborhood, or prospective owners of the condominium project, the Mayor may
deny condominium approval with appropriate findings of fact.
   D.   Authority To Proceed: The effect of condominium approval by the Mayor
shall entitle the owner or developer to proceed with obtaining building
permits, giving notice to tenants, prepare documents for recording, and
otherwise proceed with the project with all aspects being in conformance with
the conditions of approval and subject to certification and recording. The sale
of condominium units, the recording of records of survey, and the recording of
declarations, however, shall not be accomplished prior to certification.
   E.   Expiration Of Approval: Condominium approval shall expire and become
null and void after two (2) years from the date of approval, unless a
submission for certification has been made in conformance with the provisions
set forth herein. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-9-7: IMPROVEMENTS PERFORMANCE BONDS:
Performance bonds or other assurances of performance for the installation of
required improvements in a condominium project may be posted in accordance with
City bonding standards, if weather conditions, acts of God, or other
circumstance beyond the control of the applicant, make it infeasible or
impractical to complete the improvements prior to certification or recording.
Posting of bonds or other assurances may not be used to guarantee completion of
required fire separation or correction of Code violations which are deemed to
be hazardous to the life or safety of occupants. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-9-8: AMENDED SUBMISSIONS:
Within thirty (30) days after the Mayor has disapproved any project, the
developer may file with the Planning Commission appropriate materials altered
to correct all deficiencies specified in the action of the Mayor. Upon said
filing, the matter shall be reconsidered without additional fee. (Ord. 2000-23,
7-18-2000)
11-9-9: APPEAL OF PLANNING COMMISSION'S OR MAYOR'S ACTION:
Any person aggrieved by or affected by any decision of the Planning Commission
or the Mayor related to a condominium project may appeal said decision by
filing a written notice of appeal with the Hearings Officer within ten (10)
days of said decision. Said notice of appeal shall specify the grounds of the
appeal and circumstances related thereto. (Ord. 2017-29, 5-16-2017)
11-9-10: SUBMISSION REQUIRED; CONDOMINIUM CONVERSION:
As an element of any application for a condominium which includes the
conversion of existing structures, the owner or developer shall submit a
"report of property condition" which is intended to ensure that the standards
of the declaration appropriately address existing and future conditions related
to maintenance, upkeep and operation as referenced by Utah Code Annotated
section 57-8-13. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-9-11: INFORMATION REQUIRED:
   A.   The report of property condition shall be submitted to the community
development director and shall contain the following information:
      1.   The age of the building or buildings, with copies of original
building plans and a disclosure of whether or not the actual building conforms
to the plans.
      2.   Condition of structural elements, including: foundations, walls,
mechanical systems, electrical system, plumbing system, and boiler and furnace.
The plan shall also show which parts of the system are maintained in common and
which are maintained by individual units.
      3.   Size of water service lines from meter to main and from main to
buildings.
      4.   Size and location of sewer laterals.
      5.   Capacity of electrical service for each unit (measured in amperes).
      6.   Condition of paving materials on private streets (if any).
      7.   Condition of paving or surfacing material on driveways, parking
areas, sidewalks, curbs, etc. Detailed plan of parking and traffic circulation.
      8.   Condition of paint or exterior surfaces of all buildings and
structures.
      9.   All known conditions constituting deficiencies.
      10.   All known conditions which may require repair or replacement within
the next succeeding five (5) year period.
   B.   The above report may be referred back to the applicant by the city for
additional detail as is necessary to adequately evaluate the physical condition
of the building, equipment and premises. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-9-12: REPORT OF BUILDING OFFICIAL:
   A.   At the time of submission of an application for a condominium which
involves the conversion of any existing buildings, the building inspection
division shall make an inspection of the proposed condominium project to
determine compliance with the life-safety provisions of the international
building code as adopted by the city.
   B.   Prior to planning commission consideration of a condominium project
involving conversion of existing building, the building inspection division
shall submit a report to said commission specifying any deficiencies of life
safety standards of the international building code which are found to exist in
the project. This report of the building inspection division shall be submitted
to the planning commission as an element of the "report of property condition".
(Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code)
11-9-13: MINIMUM STANDARDS REQUIRED:
To achieve the purposes and objectives of this title, all proposals for a
condominium development or conversion shall be made pursuant to the provisions
of this chapter. The standards and criteria contained herein are intended to
provide assurances that the geographical layout of the project is accomplished
in a manner which is attractive and is not detrimental to the functioning of
the project or surrounding areas; and that the contents of the declaration
assure proper operation, construction, maintenance and upkeep of all utilities,
facilities, recreation areas, and roads and parking areas within the
development. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-9-14: PARKING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Conformance Required: Each unit in a condominium development,
irrespective of size, shall conform to the parking provisions contained in
title 10, chapter 18 of this code.
   B.   Recreational Vehicles: In addition to any other parking requirements,
at least one space per four (4) dwelling units for recreational vehicles and
boat storage shall be provided. These spaces may be owned in common or by the
homeowners' association. If conditions within a condominium conversion preclude
compliance with this requirement, a provision shall be placed in the bylaws or
declaration precluding the parking of recreational vehicles and boats within
the condominium development, and such preclusion shall be strictly enforced by
the management. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-9-15: UTILITY REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Separate Meters; Exception: Each condominium unit within a development
shall be separately metered for gas, electricity and water, unless the
declaration provides for the homeowners' association to pay the cost of
services and prorate those costs to unit owners on an equitable basis. (Such
declaration must disclose to the unit owners that nonpayment of utility bills
by the association may result in loss of utility service.)
   B.   Accessible Individual Shutoffs: Each unit shall be provided with
readily accessible individual shutoff valves, safety devices, or switches for
water, gas and electrical services. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-9-16: MECHANICAL AND HEATING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Each condominium unit shall be equipped with its own heating system,
except where a central water or steam system is present.
   B.   Each condominium unit shall be provided with its own means of
controlling temperature in the unit when the building utilizes a central
heating plant. All mechanical work and repairs shall be completed under a
permit and shall comply with all applicable building, health and fire codes.
(Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-9-17: CONVERSION NOTICE REQUIRED:
   A.   Required: As part of the application for approval of a condominium
project when said project involves the conversion of an existing structure
where the structure has been occupied by tenants prior to application for a
conversion, the developer or owner shall provide notice of intended conversion
to said tenants by certified mail. Said notice shall be provided at least
ninety (90) days prior to required vacation of the premises and at least one
hundred twenty (120) days before any construction associated with the
conversion begins.
   B.   Exception: This notice requirement shall not apply to structures that
have remained totally vacant for a period of at least one month prior to filing
of an application for a conversion; nor shall it preclude the certification of
a project prior to the expiration date in an instance where every tenant has
executed a waiver relinquishing his/her of notice under this provision. (Ord.
2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-9-18: CONTENT OF NOTICE OF CONVERSION:
The tenant notice required by this chapter shall include:
   A.   Intent: The specified intent of the owner to accomplish a conversion of
the building to a condominium project and an indication of need to have the
units therein vacated.
   B.   Estimated Dates Of Termination: The estimated dates of termination of
occupancy by tenants which shall not be less than ninety (90) days from the
date of notice; and an indication of the approximate dates of construction
which shall not be less than one hundred twenty (120) days from the date of
notice. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-9-19: SUBMISSION OF NOTICE VERIFICATION:
   A.   Required: Prior to or in conjunction with submission of documentation
for certification and recording, the owner or developer shall submit to the
planning commission a copy of said notice, together with a list identifying
names and apartments or unit numbers, for all tenants within the condominium
conversion project. The notice copy and list shall also be accompanied by an
affidavit certifying that all tenants within the condominium project have been
personally delivered a copy of the notice or mailed said notice by registered,
certified mail, and that the same were in fact delivered.
   B.   Conditions For Granting Certification: The mayor shall not grant
certification of a condominium conversion project until said copy of notice,
list, affidavit have been received by the planning commission and filed with
the city recorder. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-9-20: UNLAWFUL TO SELL OR LEASE:
It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, partnership or association to
sell, contract to sell, or to lease any unit of any condominium or any other
portion thereof until final record of survey plat, in full compliance with the
provision of this title, has been certified and signed by the mayor and duly
recorded in the office of the county recorder. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
CHAPTER 10
SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR
SECTION:
11-10-1: Approval Of City Engineer
11-10-2: Private Construction; Compliance
11-10-3: Permit; Agreement To Comply
11-10-4: Inspection Costs
11-10-5: Driveway; Permit Required
11-10-6: Ordinary Repairs Defined
11-10-7: Extraordinary Repairs Defined
11-10-8: New Work Defined
11-10-9: Repair, Removal Or Replacement Of Defective Sidewalks, Curbs And
Gutters
11-10-1: APPROVAL OF CITY ENGINEER:
All sidewalks shall be constructed in accordance with the plans and
specifications of the city engineer's office, which work shall be inspected and
approved by the city engineer's office. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-10-2: PRIVATE CONSTRUCTION; COMPLIANCE:
It shall be unlawful for any person, either as owner, agent servant, contractor
or employee, to construct any sidewalk in the city unless such sidewalk be
constructed to lines and grades as given and established by the city engineer,
unless special permission to deviate from such lines and grades is first
obtained from mayor. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-10-3: PERMIT; AGREEMENT TO COMPLY:
It shall be unlawful for any person, either as owner, agent, servant,
contractor or employee, to construct any permanent sidewalk in the city,
without having first obtained approval from the city engineer to do so. The
acceptance of such approval shall be deemed an agreement upon the part of such
person to construct said sidewalk in accordance with the standard
specifications of the city or as specified by the city engineer; and in
accordance with alignments and grades approved by the city engineer. When the
walk is extended from the main sidewalk to the back of the curb already
constructed, there shall be placed between the back of the curb and walk, an
expansion joint conforming to the standard specifications of the city. It shall
be unlawful to construct any such sidewalk in violation of the standard
specifications of the city. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-10-4: INSPECTION COSTS:
   A.   Construction By Property Owners: Where property owners construct
sidewalks, curb and gutters, the cost of indicating grades and lines and
inspection shall be paid by the property owner before approval for construction
is given. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
   B.   Fees: The charges for inspection and grade setting will be according to
the adopted fee schedule. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code)
11-10-5: DRIVEWAY; PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to construct any driveway across sidewalk
space, or to cut or change the construction of sidewalk, curb or gutter for the
purpose of making a driveway, without first making written application to the
city engineer and obtaining from the city engineer approval to do so. The
acceptance of such approval shall be deemed an agreement on the part of such
person to construct the driveway in accordance with standard specifications of
the city or as specified by the city engineer. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-10-6: ORDINARY REPAIRS DEFINED:
"Ordinary repairs" on sidewalks, within the provisions of this title, shall be
deemed to be such repairs as shall not exceed, in cost, ten percent (10%) of
the cost of laying a concrete sidewalk over a given surface. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-
18-2000)
11-10-7: EXTRAORDINARY REPAIRS DEFINED:
"Extraordinary repairs", within the provisions of this title, shall be deemed
to be such repairs as shall exceed ten percent (10%) and not exceed fifty
percent (50%) of the cost of laying a concrete sidewalk over a given surface.
(Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-10-8: NEW WORK DEFINED:
"New work", under the provisions of this title, shall be deemed to be all
sidewalk construction work, which shall exceed fifty percent (50%) of the cost
of laying a concrete sidewalk over a given surface. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-10-9: REPAIR, REMOVAL OR REPLACEMENT OF DEFECTIVE SIDEWALKS, CURBS AND
GUTTERS:
The purpose of this section is to avoid liability to the city and to the owners
of private property because of defective sidewalks.
   A.   Authority: The city may, on its own initiative or at the request of
others, construct, reconstruct, repair, or replace sidewalks, curbs and
gutters, located on public property. To provide a comprehensive approach for
such construction, repair or replacement, the city administration may adopt a
policy statement setting forth standards for annual inspection, planning,
construction, repair and replacement. The policy manual may also establish
criteria for setting priorities for repair or replacement, based upon hazard to
the public; and may further provide for phased implementation based upon the
seriousness of existing and potential hazards and the availability of funds.
   B.   Considerations: It shall be the sole prerogative of the city to decide
the necessity and the extent of the construction, extraordinary repairs or
replacements to be preformed by the city or its agent. Conditions to be
considered by the city when determining whether sidewalks, curbs and gutters
should be constructed, repaired or replaced pursuant to this section shall
include, but not be limited to:
      1.   Broken sidewalk panels; or
      2.   Panels having a different elevation at the junction thereof; or
      3.   Sidewalk panels with a deteriorated surface; or
      4.   Sidewalks not conforming with the requirements of the Americans with
disabilities act (ADA); or
      5.   A finding that the condition of the sidewalk is hazardous for
anticipated users thereof; and
      6.   A finding that inclusion of the proposed repairs in a special
improvement district is not practical.
   C.   Request By Owner; Agreement: When the owner of real property requests
repair or replacement of sidewalk, curb or gutter abutting upon or adjacent to
the owner's land, at a time which is different than that scheduled by the city,
the city, at its option, may decline to make such out of pocket improvements
pursuant to one of the following alternative agreements, which alternative
agreement shall be chosen by mutual agreement with the owner of real property:
      1.   Have the city provide or contract for all labor and materials
required for removal, replacement or repair, with the city assuming fifty
percent (50%) of the cost and the owner assuming fifty percent (50%) of the
cost; or
      2.   Negotiate an equitable sharing of the cost of removal and
replacement based on the special or unique characteristics of the particular
sidewalk, curb and gutter right of way and the benefits to such property by
reason of the removal, replacement or repair.
   D.   Owner Caused Damage: If the owner of the real property has directly or
indirectly been the cause of damage to the subject sidewalk, curb or gutter,
the repair or replacement shall be considered a benefit to that owner and the
owner shall assume all costs attributed to the owner's actions or neglect.
   E.   Determination Of City Engineer: The city engineer, or his designee,
shall, within fifteen (15) days of any request, determine as described in this
subsection if sidewalk, curb or gutter shall be repaired, removed or replaced,
and shall make the allocation described in subsection C of this section between
the landowner and the city of the reasonable costs of repair, removal or
replacement. In the absence of the city engineer's setting forth unique
circumstances, as described in subsection C of this section, it shall be
presumed that proper allocation of costs is payment of fifty percent (50%) by
the property owner and payment of fifty percent (50%) by the city.
   F.   Owner's Obligation Of Payment; Notice Requirement: The owner's
obligation of payment described in subsection C of this section shall not
commence until thirty (30) days after the city has mailed reasonable notice
(unless the same has been waived in writing) to each owner of real property
described in subsection C of this section, which notice shall contain not less
than the following:
      1.   A description of the sidewalk, curb or gutter which has been or is
proposed to be repaired or replaced, and the reason therefor;
      2.   The cost of the repair and the allocation of that cost between the
property owner and the city; and
      3.   A statement that the property owner may appeal any claim by the city
for payment and a description of the time and manner in which the same may be
done.
   G.   Appeal: Any person directly affected by a decision of the city
engineer, or his designee, may appeal the same to the city council within
thirty (30) days.
   H.   Reasonable Terms: The city may agree to reasonable terms, including the
payment of interest, for the payment of the share of costs to be paid by the
property owner. The city may bring a civil action and collect any unpaid sum,
including interest, costs and reasonable attorney fees, which is owed pursuant
to this section.
   I.   Exception Of Applicability: This section shall not apply to the new
construction of sidewalks in subdivisions or other places. This section shall
not prohibit the repair of sidewalks for reasons other than those described,
applicable law, and city specifications. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
CHAPTER 11
STREET EXCAVATIONS
SECTION:
11-11-1: Defects To Be Reported And Repaired
11-11-2: Permit, Bond Required; Specifications Listed Generally
11-11-3: Restoration Of Surface
11-11-4: Barricades; Lights
11-11-5: Building Material On Street; Permit; Bond
11-11-6: Fence And Boardwalk Around Construction Area
11-11-7: Protection Of Street And Sidewalk Surfaces
11-11-8: Scaffold Over Street; Permit; Revocation; Bond; Fee
11-11-1: DEFECTS TO BE REPORTED AND REPAIRED:
All defects in public streets, coming to the knowledge of any officer or person
in the employ of the city, shall be by him at once communicated to the street
superintendent. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code)
11-11-2: PERMIT, BOND REQUIRED; SPECIFICATIONS LISTED GENERALLY:
   A.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to make any
excavation in any public street, lane or alley, or remove any pavement or other
materials forming any street or improvement thereon, without a permit from the
public works department.
   B.   Application; Bond: No permit for any street excavation shall be issued
until written application therefor has been made to the public works
department. The application shall be signed by the party making the excavation
or other responsible party. The applicant shall file with the community
development department a bond of indemnity to the city, with sureties to be
approved by the community development director, conditioned that the person
making the excavation will erect and maintain about said excavation, until the
street is restored to normal condition, sufficient guards, signals, barricades
and lights, to prevent accidents. "Restored to normal condition" means to
restore the street to the same condition in which it existed prior to the
excavation and to remove rocks, dirt and rubbish from the street. The bond
shall save the city harmless from any and all claims, liabilities, demands, or
damages for any and all injuries to persons or property arising in any manner
out of, or by reason of, any such excavations. Such bond shall be in the sum of
ten thousand dollars ($10.000.00), for excavations in all streets. Any person,
franchise or utility operation that, in the pursuit of his or its regular
calling, has frequent occasion to open or make excavations in the public
streets, shall file a bond with corporate surety in the sum of ten thousand
dollars ($10,000.00) conditioned as above, to cover all excavations made for a
period of two (2) years from the date of filing. Permits for excavations,
except for the replacement of railway rails and ties, in unpaved streets, must
be applied for and issued before it shall be lawful to make any such
excavations.
   C.   Manner Of Cutting: When excavating through asphalt or concrete or
beneath stone blocks, excavations shall be cut perpendicularly at the sides and
ends from the surface for the full width of all excavations to the necessary
depth. Tunnels shall be made only as approved by the city engineer.
   D.   Backfilling Requirements: Backfilling shall be performed according to
the standard specifications of the city, or as approved by the city engineer.
Barricades and all dirt, rocks and rubbish shall be removed from the street.
   E.   Notification Of Completion: After the backfilling is completed and the
street cleared, the person doing the work shall immediately notify the public
works department of its completion. However, the applicant shall not be
relieved of responsibility until the surfacing is completed.
   F.   Payment: Resurfacing of pavement or sidewalks where excavations have
been made shall be paid for and performed by the responsible party and its
contractor. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-11-3: RESTORATION OF SURFACE:
It shall be unlawful for any person having made an excavation in any street,
whether under a permit or otherwise, to fail, neglect or refuse after a period
of five (5) days after notice from the street superintendent, to restore said
street to its normal condition. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code)
11-11-4: BARRICADES; LIGHTS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person, by or for whom any excavation is
made in a public street for any purpose, to fail to cause a barricade, rail or
other sufficient fence to be placed so as to enclose such excavation, together
with the dirt, gravel or other material thrown therefrom, and to maintain such
barricade during the whole time for which such excavation continues. It shall
also be unlawful for any person to fail to have lighted lanterns or some other
proper and sufficient lights affixed to parts of said barricade, or in some
other proper manner over or near the excavation, dirt, gravel or other material
taken therefrom. Such lighting shall be kept from the beginning of twilight
through the whole of every night during all the time such excavation exists.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to maliciously or wantonly, or
without legal cause, to extinguish, remove or diminish said lights, or to tear
down or remove any rail, fence or barricade affixed in accordance with the
provisions of this section. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-11-5: BUILDING MATERIAL ON STREET; PERMIT; BOND:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to occupy or use any portion of a
public street for the erection or repair of any building abutting thereon,
without first making application to and receiving from the public works
department, a permit for the occupation or use, for building purposes, of such
portions of streets, and/or such periods of time and under such limitations and
restrictions as may be required by ordinance or by the public convenience. No
permit shall be granted to occupy more than fifteen feet (15') from the curb
line, and any such permit may be revoked by the mayor, at any time, when the
holder thereof fails to comply with any rule or regulation under which it is
granted, or when, in the opinion of the mayor, the public good requires such
revocation. No such permit shall be granted until the applicant therefor shall
have given a bond in a reasonable amount to be approved by the city engineer.
Such bond shall run to the city, and to any person injured by reason of the
failure of the principal therein to comply with the provisions of this section
and section
11-11-6 of this chapter.
   B.   No part of a street other than that so allotted shall be used for
depositing materials for work to be done or for receiving rubbish arising from
such work. All such rubbish shall be carried away by the person to whom the
permit is granted, and at such times as the city engineer may direct, and in
case of the neglect or refusal of such persons to remove such rubbish, it shall
be removed at his expense. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-11-6: FENCE AND BOARDWALK AROUND CONSTRUCTION AREA:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to occupy any portion of any of any
street while erecting or repairing a building, or making an excavation, or for
any other purpose, even with the permit provided for in section
11-11-5 of this chapter, unless he shall first build around the portion of the
street to be occupied a tight board fence. The fence shall be at least six feet
(6') high and surrounded by a good substantial boardwalk, at least six feet
(6') in width. Said fence shall be made of clean lumber, dressed on the side
facing the street, and at no time shall said fence have thereon any painted,
printed or other advertisements. All openings in said fence must be provided
with gated opening inward. When any building of two (2) or more stories in
height is being erected within the fire limits of this city, and shall have
reached the top of the first story thereof, or when any such building is being
repaired above the first story thereof, then any fence or sidewalk occupying
the street or sidewalk in front of said building shall be at once removed. The
sidewalk abutting said building shall at once be restored to the use of
pedestrians, and bridged or covered at a height of not less than nine feet (9')
above the sidewalk and ten feet (10') wide. The covering must be constructed
with lumber or timber of sufficient strength to protect pedestrians from injury
by falling materials, tools or appliances, and to the approval of the street
superintendent or building inspector as the case may be. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-
2000; amd. 2003 Code)
   B.   Any person so occupying any portion of any street shall be responsible
to the city for all injuries sustained by any person in consequence of any
failure to strictly comply with the provisions of this section.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person to place upon any building, fence
or other structure, such building, fence or other structure being within two
feet (2') of any sidewalk in this city, any paint or other substance, without
first erecting and maintaining above such sidewalk, or between the same and
such building, fence or other structure, as the case may be, a barrier
sufficient to protect pedestrians from such paint or other substance falling
upon them or from coming in contact with such paint or other substance. (Ord.
2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-11-7: PROTECTION OF STREET AND SIDEWALK SURFACES:
It shall be unlawful to place or pile, or to cause or permit to be placed or
piled, any sand, gravel, lime, cement, mortar, plaster, concrete, or any other
substance or mixture, or to allow the same to remain on any portion of any
paved street or sidewalk in the city; or to make or mix, or to cause or permit
to be made or mixed, any mortar, plaster, concrete or any other like substance
or mixture on any portion of any paved street or sidewalk in the city. (Ord.
2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-11-8: SCAFFOLD OVER STREET; PERMIT; REVOCATION; BOND; FEE:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, build, maintain, swing or
use any scaffold, ladder or staging over or upon any street or sidewalk for the
purpose of cleaning, repairing or servicing of any awning, canopy or sign, or
for any other purpose, without first obtaining from the public works department
a permit for the occupation and use of said street or sidewalk for such
purpose, and for such periods of time and under such limitations and
regulations as may be required or promulgated by the city engineer. Such permit
may be revoked by the city engineer when the holder thereof fails to comply
with any ordinance, rule or regulation under which it is granted, or when in
the opinion of the city engineer, public convenience and safety require such
revocation. When, in the opinion of the public works department, the welfare
and convenience of the public will be best served, a continuing permit,
revocable as hereinbefore provided, may be issued for the sole purpose of
cleaning and servicing awnings and signs. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
   B.   No permit shall be granted until the applicant therefor shall have
placed on file with the public works department for the benefit of the city and
the public a surety bond to be approved by the city engineer in the sum of ten
thousand dollars ($10,000.00); provided, that at any time the city engineer
shall deem the said bond inadequate for the protection of the city or the
public, the city engineer may require the bond to be in any sum not exceeding
fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00). Said bond shall run to the city and to any
person injured and shall be conditioned for the payment of all damages that may
be adjudged against said principal or surety; and shall save the city harmless
from any and all claims, liabilities or demands arising from any bodily injury
or death at any time resulting therefrom, and any damage to or destruction of
property arising in any manner from the operations being performed under the
permit.
   C.   Permits issued under this section shall be nontransferable and any
holder of a permit allowing any other person except his duly appointed
employees or agents to use said permit shall be guilty of a class C misdemeanor
and upon conviction, subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code, and shall have his permit revoked.
   D.   For the issuance of a permit provided for in this section, the public
works department shall collect a fee according to the current fee schedule
where a fee is required for a permit for the erection of any sign. (Ord. 2000-
23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code)
CHAPTER 12
ENCROACHMENTS
SECTION:
11-12-1: Building Extending Over Street
11-12-2: Fence Or Building Encroachment; Removal Required
11-12-3: Notice To Remove
11-12-4: Removal By Owner
11-12-5: Denial Of Encroachment
11-12-6: Removal By City; Penalty
11-12-7: Penalty
11-12-1: BUILDING EXTENDING OVER STREET:
It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or construct or place, or cause
to be placed, on premises belonging to him or in his possession or under his
control, any building, bay, or oriel window which shall extend over the street
line of any lot. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-12-2: FENCE OR BUILDING ENCROACHMENT; REMOVAL REQUIRED:
If any street or sidewalk is encroached upon by a fence, building, bay or oriel
window, or otherwise, the city building official shall, in writing, require the
same to be removed. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-12-3: NOTICE TO REMOVE:
Notice in writing must be given to the occupant or owner of the land, or person
causing or owning the encroachment, either personally or by mail, postage
prepaid, addressed to the owner, occupant or person causing or owning the
encroachment, at the last known post office address as disclosed by the county
assessor, said notice to specify the width of the street between the property
lines in front of the encroachment, the place and extent of the encroachment,
and requiring him to remove the same within ten (10) days thereafter. (Ord.
2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-12-4: REMOVAL BY OWNER:
It shall be unlawful for any person who caused, owns or controls said
encroachment, to fail to remove or commence to remove and diligently prosecute
its removal prior to the expiration of the ten (10) days from the service of
said notice. If the encroachment is such as to effectually obstruct and prevent
the use of the sidewalk for pedestrians or the street for vehicles, the city
building official must forthwith remove the same. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-12-5: DENIAL OF ENCROACHMENT:
If the encroachment is denied, and the owner, occupant or person controlling
the matter then charged with being an encroachment, refuses either to remove or
permit the removal thereof, the community development director must direct the
city attorney to commence an action for the removal of the same, or abating it
as a nuisance. If judgment is recovered for the city, in addition to have said
encroachment removed or abated, there shall also be recovered a fee according
to the current fee schedule for every day such encroachment remained after
notice was given for its removal, plus city legal fees. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-
2000; amd. 2003 Code)
11-12-6: REMOVAL BY CITY; PENALTY:
If the encroachment is not denied, but is not removed for five (5) days after
the notice is complete, the city building inspector may remove the same at the
expense of the owner, occupant or person controlling the same, and recover the
city's costs and expense, and also for each day the same remained after the
notice was complete, a fee according to the current fee schedule. (Ord. 2000-
23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code)
11-12-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a class
C misdemeanor and upon conviction, subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code)
CHAPTER 13
STREET NAMING AND ADDRESSING
SECTION:
11-13-1: Names Of Streets
11-13-2: House Numbering; Marking
11-13-3: Numbering System To Be Followed
11-13-4: Costs Related To Street Name Changes
11-13-5: Street Coordinates On Named Street Signs
11-13-1: NAMES OF STREETS:
All the basic streets of the city shall be known by names as follows: the
central street running east and west shall be named and designated as Center
Street; the first street running east and west, south of Center Street, shall
be named and designated as 100 South Street, the next one south, 200 South
Street, and so on in regular order to the southern limits of the city. The
first street running east and west, north of Center Street shall be named and
designated as 100 North Street, the next one north, 200 North Street, and so on
in regular order to the northern limits of the city. The center street running
north and south, shall be named and designated as Main Street; the first street
running north and south, east of Main Street, shall be named and designated as
100 East Street, the next one east, 200 East Street; and so on in regular order
to the eastern limits of the city; the first running north and south, west of
Main Street, shall be named and designated as 100 West Street, the next one
west, 200 West Street, and so on in regular order. Other street names that do
not fit into this basic grid pattern must be approved by the city council upon
petition. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-13-2: HOUSE NUMBERING; MARKING:
   A.   Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to erect a house or
building within the city limits without numbering such house or building with
the number designated by the city engineer within ten (10) days of its
issuance. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
   B.   Number Designated; Placement: When such number has been designated by
the city engineer, the owner or occupant of such house or building shall cause
a painted, carved or cast replica of the designated number. The numbers shall
be at least three inches (3") in height and of a shade opposite to the
background upon which it is mounted. It shall be placed in a conspicuous
position upon the front of such house or building, in a permanent, stationary
and durable manner, unobstructed at all times by vines, screens, or anything
that would tend to hide or obscure the number, and so that the number will be
clearly perceptible from a distance of one hundred fifty feet (150'). Upon
application being made to the city engineer, he shall issue a certificate
giving the correct street number for said house or building. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-
18-2000; amd. 2003 Code)
11-13-3: NUMBERING SYSTEM TO BE FOLLOWED:
The city engineer, in numbering houses upon the streets of the city, shall
adhere in all respects to the following system of numeration, allowing city
numbers to each side of all coordinates within the city limits: the initial
points shall be the intersection of Main and Center Streets, and the numbering
shall extend east and west, and north and south, the even numbers always on the
right hand, looking away from the initial point. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-13-4: COSTS RELATED TO STREET NAME CHANGES:
Any person who petitions for a change in the name of a street or alley shall,
unless the mayor for good cause otherwise directs, pay the cost of making and
installing new street signs required by the name change. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-
2000)
11-13-5: STREET COORDINATES ON NAMED STREET SIGNS:
Street signs erected by the city showing the name of the street shall include
on the face thereof the correct street coordinates. For example, the street
sign for "Proctor Lane" shall also include the coordinate "1300 West". (Ord.
2000-23, 7-18-2000)
CHAPTER 14
MAJOR STREET PLAN
SECTION:
11-14-1: Map Established; Filed
11-14-2: Building On Mapped Street; Prohibited
11-14-3: Building On Mapped Street; Excepted
11-14-4: Street Grades Established
11-14-1: MAP ESTABLISHED; FILED:
There is hereby established an official map of the City. Shown on the official
map are the existing public streets in the City. The map is maintained by the
City Engineer's Office. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-14-2: BUILDING ON MAPPED STREET; PROHIBITED:
For the purpose of preserving the integrity of the official map of the City, no
permit shall be issued for any building or structure or any part of a building
or structure on any land located between the mapped lines of any street as
shown on the official map of the City. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-14-3: BUILDING ON MAPPED STREET; EXCEPTED:
This chapter shall be subject to the following provisions:
The Hearings Officer shall be empowered to authorize the granting of a permit
for a building or structure or part thereof within any mapped street location
in any case in which the Hearings Officer finds:
   A.   That the property of the appellant of which such mapped street location
forms a part will not yield a reasonable return to the owner unless such permit
be granted; or
   B.   That balancing the interest of the Municipality in preserving the
integrity of the official map and the interest of the owner in the use and
benefits of the property, the grant of such permit is required by consideration
of justice and equity. Before taking any such action, the Hearings Officer
shall hold a public hearing thereon. In the event that the Hearings Officer
decides to authorize a building permit, he/she shall have the power to specify
the exact location, ground area, height and other details and conditions of
extent and character and also the duration of the building, structure or part
thereof to be permitted. (Ord. 2017-29, 5-16-2017)
11-14-4: STREET GRADES ESTABLISHED:
   A.   Whenever it shall be deemed advisable to establish a grade on any
street where no grade has been theretofore established, or to change any
established grade, the grade shall be established and set by the City Engineer
on a profile map, a copy of which shall be maintained in the Office of the City
Engineer.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or construct or to
commence the erection or construction of any building or other structure upon
the proposed alignment of any street where the grade of said street has already
been established, without first making application to the City Engineer to
indicate the grade of the street upon which said building or other structure is
to be erected, or thereafter to build to any grade other than that indicated by
the engineer. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
CHAPTER 15
INSPECTION FEE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
11-15-1: Application
11-15-2: Violations And Penalties
11-15-3: Other Inspection Fees
11-15-4: Testing And Inspection Fee
11-15-1: APPLICATION:
   A.   Inspection Fees To Be Charged: Fees are proscribed in the International
Building Code as adopted in section
9-2-1 of this Code.
   B.   Certain Residences: For residential structures including not more than
four (4) dwelling units (single-family residences, duplexes, triplexes and
fourplexes), there shall be a single building inspection fee which shall
include the cost of general building inspection, electrical inspection,
mechanical inspection and plumbing inspection. The general building inspection
fee shall be the building inspection fee described in section
10-4-1 of this Code.
   C.   Other Structures: Except as provided in subsection B of this section,
structures including five (5) or more dwelling units shall be charged separate
fees for general building inspection, electrical inspection, mechanical
inspection and plumbing inspection. The general building inspection fee shall
be the building inspection fee described in the International Building Code.
The fees for electrical inspection and plumbing inspection shall be the fees
described in the fee schedule as adopted by the City. (Ord. 2017-24, 4-18-2017)
11-15-2: VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any persons to install, connect or to utilize
any equipment anticipated in the above fee schedule without having first
obtained a permit and paid the applicable fee as in this chapter provided.
   B.   Any installation or connection made without having first obtained a
permit and paid the fees as required, shall be subject, upon notice given by
the Inspection Department, to a fee double that set forth in the fee schedule
above.
   C.   If any permit required hereunder or fee required hereby is not paid
after on notification from the Inspection Division, the person or persons
responsible shall have committed a Class C misdemeanor and upon conviction,
subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code.
   D.   In the event that the person unlawfully connecting or installing
equipment is different from the person responsible for the premises, both shall
be equally liable for any unlawful installation or connection or for failure to
obtain any permit or fee required hereunder. (Ord. 2017-24, 4-18-2017)
11-15-3: OTHER INSPECTION FEES:
The building official is hereby authorized to establish for miscellaneous
inspections required a reasonable fee to recompense the City for the cost of
inspections or for unusual circumstances not anticipated by the standard fees
established. (Ord. 2017-24, 4-18-2017)
11-15-4: TESTING AND INSPECTION FEE:
   A.   Required Prepayment Of Inspection Costs: All inspection, testing, GPS
services, and mapping, as provided and detailed within this title and the
Pleasant Grove City standard specifications and drawings, shall be paid for by
the developer. The developer shall prepay for such costs in the form of a cash
payment to Pleasant Grove City either at the pre-construction meeting or not
later than two (2) weeks from developer's receipt of calculations from the
City. If payment has not been made within the required time period, City may
issue a stop work order on the project until the fees have been paid. Prepaid
fees will be placed into an escrow account and drawn upon as costs are
incurred. If costs for these services exceed the amount in the escrow account,
they will be the responsibility of the developer and paid for prior to
receiving final acceptance at the end of the developments warranty period and
prior to release of the warranty bonding. If the developer does not pay
additional amounts, the warranty bond may be used to pay for any additional
amounts required.
   B.   Determining Pre-Payment Amount: The prepaid amount shall be two percent
(2%) of the City Engineer's construction bond estimate, as provided for under
section
11-16-1 of this title, for improvements for all bonds more than one million
dollars ($1,000,000.00); three percent (3%) for all construction bonds one
million dollars ($1,000,000.00) or less; or five thousand dollars ($5,000.00)
for all construction bonds under one hundred sixty seven thousand dollars
($167,000.00) and a minimum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) for any site
plan without a construction bond requirement. The City Engineer or his designee
may determine a pre-payment amount less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00)
in circumstances where five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) would be unreasonable,
such as in cases where building permits include a single lot development. Pre-
payment of fees shall not indemnify the developer from paying for costs, which
the City may incur, above the prepaid amount.
   C.   Tracking: The City shall establish a file for each subdivision plat to
monitor and track the inspection, testing, GPS services, or mapping progress of
the subdivision. Inspections shall be scheduled by the developer through the
Public Works Department and may be performed by City personnel or consultants
as determined necessary by the City. Services conducted by a consultant will be
tracked by the amount billed to each project and the entire amount of the bill
for those services will be reimbursed to the City using the prepaid fees.
   D.   Reimbursement: At the conclusion of a final walk through and City
acceptance of the improvements, the developer may be reimbursed any amount
remaining in the escrow account. Before final acceptance, the developer shall
submit a formal written request to determine the reimbursement amount or
additional costs, if necessary. Any reimbursement shall be given in accordance
with section
11-16-1 of this title. (Ord. 2019-2, 3-5-2019)
CHAPTER 16
PERFORMANCE BONDS FOR LAND USE AND DEVELOPMENT
SECTION:
11-16-1: Performance Bonds
11-16-1: PERFORMANCE BONDS:
This section contains provisions for performance bonds, which apply to all land
use or development. It includes, but is not limited to, zoning, subdivisions or
street improvements which are subject to regulation by the city:
   A.   Amount Required:
      1.   Construction Bond: A bond shall be posted with the city in a
principal amount of one hundred percent (100%) of the total estimated cost of
any performance which is promised to the city. The estimated cost shall be
based on the average cost paid by the city in the past for the same type of
performance, average unit bid prices as published by the Utah department of
transportation, or other resources which document costs for similar
performance. If at the time the bond amount is first calculated, or at any time
thereafter, it is foreseeable that the promised performance will take more than
one year to perform, the principal amount of the bond shall be increased by not
less than twenty five percent (25%) for each additional year of performance.
      2.   Warranty Bond: A bond shall be posted with the city in a principal
amount of ten percent (10%) of the construction bond total.
   B.   Type:
      1.   The construction bond shall be in the form of an irrevocable letter
of credit or cash on deposit with the city.
      2.   The warranty bond shall be in the form of cash on deposit with the
city.
   C.   Rights Of City: The terms of the bond shall give the city the
unqualified right, after default, to receive any part of the bond which is
necessary to complete the promised performance or to repair any inadequate
performance.
   D.   Terms Of Expiration: The bond, by its terms, shall not expire until the
city engineer has certified in writing that the promised performance is
completed. If the bond will expire prior to the completion of the bonded work,
the city engineer is authorized to declare the bond in default and have the
bond converted to a cash bond to be held by the city.
   E.   Enforcement: The city shall have the sole right to enforce the bond.
Private parties shall not be third party beneficiaries of the bond.
   F.   Partial Release: A bond may be partially released if the performance to
which it related has been satisfactorily completed; provided, that beyond work
completed, ten percent (10%) of the bond is retained to ensure completion of
the entire performance. A service charge may be charged to cover the actual
cost of processing the partial bond releases in the event of more than two (2)
partial releases. No charge will be made for the first two (2) partial
releases. A maximum of five (5) partial releases will be allowed.
   G.   Final Release: A bond may not be completely released until the city
engineer has certified in writing that the promised performance is completed.
      1.   Construction Bonds: A construction bond may not be completely
released until all performance guaranteed by the bond is completed. Upon
written approval by the city engineer, a new bond may be posted to guarantee
remaining items of performance, thus allowing a previous bond to be completely
released. Such replacement bonding must be in place prior to final release.
      2.   Warranty Bonds: A warranty bond may not be completely released until
all performance, guaranteed by the bond, is completed. A warranty bond provides
assurance of quality in the performance required by a construction bond. A time
period specified by the city engineer must pass before a warranty bond is
eligible for release. At the completion of this time period the required
performance is reviewed and any corrections needed are noted. Only when all
corrections noted are complete may the warranty bond be released. (Ord. 2010-3,
1-19-2010)
CHAPTER 17
ANNEXATION
SECTION:
11-17-1: General Requirements
11-17-2: Annexation Procedures
11-17-3: Municipal Initiation Of Annexation
11-17-4: Procedure For Petitions And Plats
11-17-5: Annexation Petition Review
11-17-1: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
In order to assure orderly growth and development of the community and protect
the general interest of the taxpaying public as well as the rights of
individual property owners who wish to annex to the city, the following
specific guidelines are established:
   A.   Fee Policy: The city's policy of requiring subdividers and developers
to provide for improvements through a bond procedure or through a special
improvement district makes it unnecessary for the city to assess general impact
fees at the time of annexation. Developers will, however, be subject to
appropriate fees to offset the cost to the city for planning and supervision of
subdividing, and the providing of utilities, as those fees are provided through
ordinances of the city, or by resolution duly passed. A party annexing property
will likewise be charged for services of the city for preparation of the
annexation plat if that work is done by the city rather than by a private
engineer or surveyor.
   B.   Property Included: Every annexation include the greatest amount of
property possible.
      1.   Piecemeal annexation of individual small properties not be allowed
if contiguous parcels, soon to be developed, are available, in order to avoid
repetitious annexation.
      2.   No pocket or islands of county jurisdiction be allowed, and that
peninsulas and irregular boundaries be minimized.
      3.   Annexation generally follow existing roads, utilities and property
lines in order to minimize the public expense for extension of main or service
lines and streets.
   C.   Utility Extensions Limited: City utilities and services not be extended
to unincorporated properties on the fringes of the city nor to islands of
unincorporated property. In order to provide for orderly growth and development
in the city and to avoid confusion and undue cost to the taxpayers, all utility
and service hookons shall be limited to incorporated areas of the city and
shall not be made available extraterritorially. The only exception shall be to
those extensions which are made pursuant to agreements with other units of
government under the interlocal government cooperation act, or by specific
approval of the municipal council on request of the city council.
   D.   Utilities To Annexed Areas: Utilities be extended to annexed areas as
soon as practicable after annexation.
      1.   Each annexation should require a disclosure by the developer of
anticipated needs of utilities and street improvements and a timetable of
anticipated development. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
      2.   Needed utilities be extended into the annexed area as soon as
practicable subject to budgetary limitations and that extensions of main and
service lines be chargeable to the property development rather than to the
public generally. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code)
11-17-2: ANNEXATION PROCEDURES:
Which one of the following annexation procedures are followed will be
determined by whether the property owner, or the city exercises the prerogative
of initiating the annexation:
   A.   Annexation By Property Owner: It is hereby recognized that the city's
policy shall be to allow the property owner contiguous to the city boundaries,
absent some reasonable public interest, to be and remain in control of both the
discretion as to whether to be annexed into the city and the timing in
conjunction with such annexation.
   B.   Petition: When initiated by the property owner, the city petition for
annexation shall be as follows: (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
      1.   The property owner or owners shall submit to the city a petition for
annexation in a form meeting the criteria established by state law. (Ord. 2000-
23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code)
      2.   Attached to and as part of the petition shall be an accurate survey
plat of the property to be annexed accurately describing the existing city
boundaries and each individual ownership sought to be annexed, including an
accurate legal description of the property to be annexed.
      3.   There shall be attached a statement as to the anticipated timetable
for development of the property being annexed. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-17-3: MUNICIPAL INITIATION OF ANNEXATION:
It shall be the policy of the city to annex unincorporated areas without a
petition if:
   A.   The annexation is an island within or a peninsula contiguous to the
municipality.
   B.   The majority of the area consists of residential or commercial
development.
   C.   The area proposed for annexation requires the delivery of municipal
type services.
   D.   The municipality has provided most or all of the municipal type
services to the area for more than one year. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-17-4: PROCEDURE FOR PETITIONS AND PLATS:
The procedure for processing annexation petitions and plats shall be as
follows:
   A.   Submission: A petition and proper plat certified by a licensed engineer
or surveyor shall be submitted to the city recorder as set forth in the state
law.
   B.   Action Of Community Development Director: The petition and plat shall
be forwarded to the community development director who shall determine the
feasibility of expanding the annexation boundaries. The plat and description
shall also be returned to the city recorder to prepare the "notice of
certification".
   C.   Staff Review: The annexation proposal shall be reviewed by the staff
review committee at a meeting called by the community development director.
   D.   Report And Recommendation: The staff review committee shall prepare an
impact report and recommendation on the proposed annexation to be reviewed by
the planning commission and city council at their regular meeting.
   E.   Public Hearing; Recommendation To City Council: The planning
commission, upon referral from the community development director, shall hold a
public hearing and make a recommendation on the annexation proposal to the city
council. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-17-5: ANNEXATION PETITION REVIEW:
   A.   Staff Review Committee: General annexation procedure shall be that
provided by state law; provided, however, that the city council shall not take
final action on any petition until the same has been reviewed by the staff
review committee. The staff review committee, for purposes of this review,
shall be composed of the following, or their designees:
      1.   The city engineer.
      2.   The public works director. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
      3.   The fire chief.
      4.   The police chief.
      5.   The zoning administrator.
      6.   The community development director. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd.
2003 Code)
   B.   Staff Report: The staff review committee will review each annexation
requirement and prepare a staff report with a recommendation for the city
council and planning commission indicating an evaluation of the following
information: (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code; Ord. 2004-19, 8-17-2004)
      1.   The ability to meet annexation policy criteria.
      2.   An accurate map of the proposed annexation area showing the
boundaries and property ownership within the area, the topography of the area
and major natural features (e.g., drainage channels, wooded areas, areas of
high water table, etc.).
      3.   Current and potential population of the area and the current
residential densities.
      4.   Land uses presently existing and those proposed.
      5.   Statement as to how the proposed area, or its potential land use,
would contribute to the achievement of the goals and policies of the city
general plan.
      6.   Assessed valuation of the current properties.
      7.   Potential demand for various city services, and the need for land
use regulation in the area.
         a.   Distance from existing utility lines.
         b.   Special requirements (e.g., floodplain, hillside ordinances,
etc.).
         c.   Distance to public schools, parks and shopping centers.
         d.   Traffic generated by expected land uses.
      8.   The effect that the annexation will have upon city boundaries and
whether the annexation will ultimately create potential for islands,
undesirable boundaries and difficult service areas. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
      9.   Specific timetable for extending services would be furnished.
      10.   Potential revenue versus service costs.
      11.   An estimate of the tax consequences to residents of the area to be
annexed into the city. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code)
      12.   Recommendation or attitudes of the other local government
jurisdictions regarding the proposal and potential impact of the annexation on
general county economic needs, goals or objectives. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
CHAPTER 18
GENERAL PLAN
SECTION:
11-18-1: General Provisions
11-18-2: Plan Preparation
11-18-3: Plan Adoption
11-18-4: Amendment Of Plan
11-18-5: Effect Of Plan On Public Uses
11-18-1: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   The city shall prepare and adopt a comprehensive, long range plan for:
      1.   Present and future needs of the city; and
      2.   Growth and development of the land within the city.
   B.   The plan may provide for:
      1.   Health, general welfare, safety, energy conservation,
transportation, prosperity, civic activities, aesthetics and recreational,
educational and cultural opportunities;
      2.   The reduction of the waste of physical, financial or human resources
that result from either excessive congestion or excessive scattering of
population;
      3.   The efficient and economical use, conservation and production of the
supply of:
         a.   Food and water; and
         b.   Drainage, sanitary and other facilities and resources;
      4.   The use of energy conservation and solar and renewable energy
resources;
      5.   The protection of urban development; and
      6.   The protection and promotion of air quality.
   C.   The city council may determine the comprehensiveness, extent and format
of the general plan based upon recommendations from the planning commission.
   D.   The plan will generally cover a fifteen (15) to twenty (20) year time
period and will be brought up to date by the planning commission at five (5)
year intervals. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-18-2: PLAN PREPARATION:
   A.   The planning commission shall make and recommend to the city council a
proposed general plan for the area within the city. The plan may include areas
outside the boundaries of the city.
   B.   The general plan, with the accompanying maps, plats, charts and
descriptive and explanatory matter, shall show the planning commission's
recommendation for the development of the territory covered by the plan, and
may include, among other things:
      1.   A land use element that:
         a.   Designates the proposed general distribution and location and
extent of uses of land for housing, business, industry, agriculture,
recreation, education, public buildings and grounds, open space, and other
categories of public and private uses of land as appropriate; and
         b.   May include a statement of the standards of population density
and building intensity recommended for the various land use categories covered
by the plan.
      2.   A transportation and circulation element consisting of the general
location and extent of existing and proposed freeways, arterial and collector
streets, mass transit, and any other modes of transportation that are
appropriate, all correlated with the land use element of the plan;
      3.   An environmental element of the plan:
         a.   The protection, conservation, development and use of natural
resources, including the quality of air, forests, soils and other waters,
harbors, fisheries, wildlife, minerals, and other natural resources; and
         b.   The reclamation of land, flood control, prevention and control of
the pollution of streams and other waters, regulation of the use of land on
hillsides, stream channels and other environmentally sensitive areas, the
prevention, control and correction of the erosion of soils, protection of
watersheds and wetlands, and the mapping of known geologic hazards.
      4.   A public services and facilities element showing general plans for
sewage, waste disposal, drainage, local utilities, rights of way, easements,
and facilities for them, police and fire protection, and other public services;
      5.   A rehabilitation, redevelopment and conservation element consisting
of plans and programs for:
         a.   Historic preservation; and
         b.   The element of blight and for redevelopment, including housing
sites, business and industrial sites, and public building sites;
      6.   An economic element composed of appropriate studies and an economic
development plan that may include review of municipal revenue and expenditures,
revenue sources, identification of base and residentiary industry, primary and
secondary market area, employment, and retail sales activity;
      7.   Recommendations for implementing the plan, including the use of
zoning ordinances, subdivision ordinances, capital improvement plans, and other
appropriate actions; and
      8.   Any other elements that the municipality considers appropriate.
(Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-18-3: PLAN ADOPTION:
   A.   Process: The plan adoption process includes:
      1.   After completing a proposed general plan for all or part of the area
within the city, the planning commission shall schedule and hold a public
hearing on the proposed general plan.
      2.   The planning commission shall provide reasonable notice of the
public hearing at least fourteen (14) days before the date of the hearing.
      3.   After the public hearing, the planning commission may make changes
to the proposed general plan.
   B.   Forward To Council: The planning commission shall then forward the
proposed general plan to the city council.
   C.   Action Of City Council: The city council shall:
      1.   Hold a public hearing on the proposed general plan recommended to it
by the planning commission.
      2.   Provide reasonable notice of the public hearing at least fourteen
(14) days before the date of the hearing.
   D.   Modifications Authorized: After the public hearing, the city council
may make any modifications to the proposed general plan that it considers
appropriate.
   E.   Decision Of Council: The city council may:
      1.   Adopt the proposed general plan without amendment;
      2.   Amend the proposed general plan and adopt it as amended; or
      3.   Reject the proposed general plan.
   F.   Applicability Of Plan: The general plan is an advisory guide for land
use decisions. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-18-4: AMENDMENT OF PLAN:
   A.   Authority: The legislative body may amend the general plan by following
the procedures required by section
11-18-3 of this chapter. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
   B.   Planning Commission Determination: For proposed general plan amendments
less than five (5) acres in size, the planning commission may determine and
must inform the applicant regarding which factors found in section
11-18-2 of this chapter will need to be addressed by the applicant. (Ord. 2000-
23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code)
   C.   Meetings And Studies: Upon application for a general plan amendment,
the planning staff in conjunction with the planning commission chairperson will
determine what neighborhood meetings and additional studies may be required.
Depending on the complexity and size of a general plan amendment, the process
could take between two (2) and six (6) months. The staff and chairperson will
determine when the amendment will be presented to the full commission. Before
the commission can hear any request, studies and neighborhood meetings should
be held. The responsibility and cost of these requirements will be the
responsibility of the applicant. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
11-18-5: EFFECT OF PLAN ON PUBLIC USES:
   A.   After the city council has adopted a general plan or any amendment to
the general plan or any amendments to the general plan, no street, park or
other public way, ground, place or space, no publicly owned building or
structure, and no public utility, whether publicly or privately owned, may be
constructed or authorized until and unless:
      1.   It conforms to the plan; or
      2.   It has been considered by the planning commission and, after
receiving the advice of the planning commission, approved by the city council
as an amendment to the general plan.
   B.   Before any action: (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
      1.   Accepting, widening, removing, extending, relocating, narrowing,
vacating, abandoning, changing the use, acquiring land for, or selling or
leasing any street or other public way, place, property or structure, the city
council shall submit the proposal to the planning commission for its review and
recommendations. (Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000; amd. 2003 Code)
      2.   If the city council approves any of the items contained in
subsection B1 of this section, the city council shall amend the general plan.
(Ord. 2000-23, 7-18-2000)
